Futures for the S&P 500 index, Nasdaq 100 and Dow Jones industrial average were fractionally higher Monday morning.XLast week, the Nasdaq composite edged lower, even with Apple (AAPL) and Tesla (TSLA) surging following earnings reports. The Dow industrials continued to climb to new highs, extending a winning streak to nine sessions. The S&P 500 index edged higher.Nasdaq 100 futures rose nearly 0.1% above fair value. S&P 500 and Dow futures were slightly higher.Earnings season is now past its peak. But there are a number of notable sectors reporting in force this week.Five Chinese internets report this week: YY (YY,) Sina (SINA), Weibo (WB), Autohome (ATHM) and NetEase (NTES). YY, Sina, Weibo, Autohome and NetEase all boast best-possible 99 Composite Ratings. The Composite Rating combines several proprietary IBD ratings. Long-time winners often boast Composite Ratings of 95 or better near the start of their runs.Sina and Weibo are near buy points, with Sina owning a majority of Weibo. NetEase is also in a short consolidation, though it's a four-stage base that can be riskier.A number of retailers, including department stores Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS), Nordstrom (JWN) and J.C. Penney (JCP) report earnings. None of these retailers is performing well in the face of competition from Amazon (AMZN) and Wal-Mart (WMT), but investors will be looking for any signs that one or more is finding some success.CBS (CBS), Walt Disney (DIS) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) also are reporting. All own network and broadcast channels. How are they faring regarding viewers, subscribers and advertisers in the face of a massive shift in viewing habits to Netflix (NFLX), Hulu and other streaming services.Highly rated fiber play Lumentum (LITE), graphics-AI-automotive chip play Nvidia (NVDA) and struggling social network Snap (SNAP) are among the others reporting.RELATED:These 4 Tech Giants Near Buy Points; 2 Others Diverge From Key LevelsNvidia, Disney, China Stocks Lead 'Monster' Week: Investing Action PlanStocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth StocksThe Big Picture: Small Caps Add A New WrinkleInside IBD 50: Charts Show Why These 4 Stocks Sold Off On EarningsWill These 2 Chinese Stocks Pop Or Drop On Q2 Earnings?

As brick-and-mortar department stores look for ways to revive their business, J.C. Penney (JCP) announced Thursday that it is opening toy shops within its physical locations. XHasbro (HAS), Mattel (MAT), Playmobil and Fisher Price are some of the brands that will line the shelves of the new section, which will be placed next to its existing Disney (DIS) Collection in stores. Its online offerings have "doubled" over the last year and there are plans to expand that assortment by the holidays, said the company.Management said the move follows its decision last holiday season to offer toys, in a nostalgic callback to its early Christmas catalogs."We were extremely pleased by customer response and confidently made the decision to grow our toy assortment in stores and at JCPenney.com," said the company's chief merchant, John Tighe, in a statement. "We know that shoppers buy toys year-round and by creating a fun, inviting toy shop, with some of the biggest brands and hottest products, we will entice families to shop and spend more at JCPenney."The shop-in-shop concept has bred success before for the department store. Its Sephora locations in store have helped J.C. Penney to deliver "significant" same-store sales growth, said CEO Marvin Ellison during a May call with analysts, and remains a growing business. By the end of the year, there will be Sephora shops in 75% of J.C. Penney locations.Even beauty hasn't been totally immune, however, as several department stores have reportedly begun offering discounts on cosmetics.Apparel, however, underperformed overall same-store sales in J.C. Penney's most recent quarter."We have no great optimism that we're going to swing apparel to positive comps overall," said Ellison on the call.Shares of J.C. Penney rallied 7.8% to 4.98 in the stock market today, closing above its 50-day moving average for the first time this year. Retailers aren't having a bad day so far, as big-box retailer Target (TGT) gained 4.8% on a boosted earnings outlook. Macy's (M) added 4.1%, and Kohl's (KSS) gained 4.8%.RELATED:Target Jumps On Positive Same-Store Sales, Earnings GuidanceHere Is The Latest Retailer Possibly Headed Toward LiquidationNordstrom Nearly Halves Gain As Family Explores 'Going Private'Macy's Triggers New Retail Rout On Gross Margins Warning

While e-commerce behemoth Amazon.com (AMZN) continues to disrupt retailers like Macy's (M) and Kohl's (KSS), 2015 IPO Ollie's Bargain Outlet (OLLI) continues to grow steadily as its stock continues to climb.After pulling back Monday, Ollie's is trading about 1% above a 44.18 buy point from a third-stage flat base , with earnings on tap for the end of August.Meanwhile, Amazon has pulled back from the all-time high it briefly hit on July 27 and is now testing support at its 50-day line and the benchmark share price of 1,000.X Ollie's, a Pennsylvania-based operator of over 230 discount stores, saw both earnings and sales growth rise last quarter. Earnings-per-share increased from 22% to 25%. Revenue rose from 16% to 17%.Analysts expect earnings-per-share growth of 19% for the quarter, and 21% growth for the full year. Annual growth estimates were recently revised upward.Ollie's Bargain Outlet has a 96 Composite Rating and holds the No. 1 rank among its peers in the Retail-Discount & Variety industry group. Five Below (FIVE) and Big Lots (BIG) are also among the group's highest-rated stocks.Note: Dates for earnings reports are estimates and subject to change. Macy's (M) shares hit a seven-year low and Ulta Beauty (ULTA) breached its key 200-day moving average amid a report that department stores are now discounting prestige beauty products, a segment once thought to be untouchable by price slashers.XLord & Taylor and Macy's-owned Bloomingdale's are following Macy's in offering slight discounts on beauty products, according to the Wall Street Journal.Macy's fell 7% to 21.08 in the stock market today, hitting its worst levels since September 2010 amid the latest retail rout. Kohl's (KSS) shares skidded 4.2%, cutting its 50-day. Kohl's is near a recent 52-week low. Nordstrom (JWN) tumbled 2.7% to 46.24.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) sank through its 200-day line for the first time in 16 months. Ulta fell 2.9% to 268.82, continuing a downward march from a recent all-time high of 314.86 in early June.Specialty beauty retailers Ulta Beauty and Sephora have typically been regarded as Amazon (AMZN)-resistant companies, immune to the promotional downward spiral facing apparel sellers and the woes befalling Macy's and other department stores. Both also have strong rewards programs that court shoppers' loyalty.But Monday's story in the Journal, while not indicative of greater discounting at Ulta or Sephora, may point to concerns over potential ripple effects. It is unclear how much pressure specialty beauty retailers would experience should heavy cosmetics discounting at department stores become widespread.Estee Lauder (EL), a prestige brand found at major department stores (and to a certain degree at Ulta and Sephora), fell below its 50-day moving average for the first time in three months. Shares closed off session lows, losing just 1 cent to 94.27, but that's below the rising support line.Estee Lauder cleared a 94.57 entry point from a cup-with-handle base in late May, rising as high as 98.40. But the stock closed below that entry on Friday.RELATED:These Stocks May Be 'More Investable' After Amazon-Whole Foods Deal

Known retail disruptor Amazon.com (AMZN) is at it again, reportedly.WWD said Wednesday, citing market sources, that online cosmetics-retailer Violet Grey could partner with Amazon to sell its luxury brands through the e-commerce behemoth.Violet Grey was founded in 2013 by Cassandra Grey, the wife of late ex-Paramount Pictures CEO Brad Grey. The company has a brick-and-mortar presence on Melrose Place in Los Angeles, offering "expertly curated beauty products and exclusive offerings, all tested and approved by Hollywood's leading hairstylists, skin care experts, and makeup artists."X Its e-commerce site features photo shoots with celebrities such as "Game of Thrones" star Emilia Clarke and stories like "Lessons on Hair Volume" and "Violette's Rules of Foundation."Why does it matter? The news of Violet Grey's potential deal with Amazon is likely what's weighing on specialty retailer Ulta Beauty (ULTA) in the stock market today. Ulta fell 3.65% to 247.24, hitting a fresh 2017 low intraday as shares continue their downward trajectory from early June.Stifel analyst Mark Astrachan, who wrote that he was "unsurprised" by the report, called a potential Amazon-Violet Grey deal a "negative for retailers, including Ulta and Sephora, and to (a) lesser extent department stores, which rely on beauty to drive foot traffic."Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS) and peers certainly have their own troubles, and a recent Wall Street Journal report — on department stores discounting prestige beauty products — sent Macy's shares to a seven-year low. J.C. Penney (JCP) has seen beauty sales grow, thanks to its Sephora shop-in-shops.One small online beauty retailer getting the backing of Amazon doesn't pose an imminent threat to cosmetics stores or retailers that carry makeup and skin care. The worry, though, is what it indicates about Amazon's interest in entering the space — and how hard the e-commerce heavy will pummel away once it has something in its cross hairs.Grocery stores, after all, could tell its counterparts in beauty a thing or two.Estee Lauder (EL) and L'Oreal-owned brands are also sold on Violet Grey."We ultimately think it makes sense for companies such as Estee Lauder, L'Oreal, and LVMH to offer a limited assortment of prestige beauty brands for sale on Amazon, given the substantial shift in consumer shopping behavior online," said Astrachan.He thinks the owners of brands sold on Violet Grey would have right of refusal to sell on Amazon, but if a deal were to happen, "we would anticipate the independent brands would be most likely to embrace Amazon, with a likely far-more-limited assortment of larger brands being offered for sale in time."Estee Lauder shares rose 0.2% intraday to 98.92. The stock is at the edge of the buy zone from a 94.57 cup-with-handle base entry point.Prestige beauty brands keep a tight cap on distribution in order to assert control over pricing and brand image. But this news and e-commerce focus is "modestly favorable" to both L'Oreal and Estee Lauder, said Astrachan, especially since a broader online presence would ease Estee Lauder's reliance on mid-tier department stores for its sales.... Exactly what kind of impact Amazon is looking to make on the beauty space. And it might be too early to panic, says one expert.Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy said that Violet Grey's estimated revenue is "well below" $5 million a year (while noting Ulta's market cap has taken a $550 million hit so far Wednesday), and that it has a "tiny" social-media presence compared to Ulta and Estee Lauder. But it does have "decent" traction with celebrities, she said.And according to Piper Jaffray, Violet Grey carries 130 brands, mostly skin care and cosmetics. But only 15 of the brands overlap with Ulta's offerings, such as Dior, Giorgio Armani, MAC and others."Bottom line, while we recognize the "headline" risk of seeing AMZN & any category (in this case, beauty) in the same line, we don't see a near-term risk for the beauty category being disintermediated by Amazon at this juncture," wrote Murphy.She has an overweight rating and 330 price target on Ulta Beauty.Amazon, meanwhile, rose 1.2% to 1,052.80, hitting a record high but in buy range from a 1,016,60 entry. Amazon reports earnings Thursday afternoon.RELATED:Macy's Hits 7-Year Low, Ulta Slices 200-Day As Beauty Gets OldIf You Won't Come For J.C. Penney's Clothes, Come For The Toys?These Stocks May Be 'More Investable' After Amazon-Whole Foods DealAmazon-Whole Foods Merger Could Be 'Category Killer' For Food, Eateries

The major indexes stocks rose slight in late morning trade in the stock market today after briefly turning negative. The tech-heavy Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average were all up 0.1%.Among the Dow industrials, Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) moved up 1.5% to pace the advancers after rival Target (TGT) provided upbeat same-store sales and raised its earnings guidance.XOn the downside, McDonald's (MCD) fell 0.9%. Shares of the restaurant chain are sitting about 20% from their most recent buy point — a cup-with-handle's 130.10 entry.In the wake of Target's raised guidance, retailers rose across the board — particularly department stores. Target and Kohl's (KSS) rallied more than 3% each. Both stocks remain in significant long-term downtrends.Among earnings reporters, Delta Air Lines (DAL) led the overall airline group lower, descending nearly 2% after its reported Q2 results fell short of estimates. Shares of the airline operator are within 3% of new highs. Meanwhile, Southwest Airlines (LUV) fell 0.1%. The stock is just out of the 5% buy range from a 58.83 cup-with-handle buy point.Yandex (YNDX) soared 15% to 31.47 after Uber Technologies withdrew from Russia and agreed to merge its ride-hailing operations with the Russian internet company. Yandex shares jumped out of a flat base with a 29.23 entry.Among analyst actions Wednesday, Pulte Group (PHM) was upgraded to neutral from underperform at Wedbush, with shares up 0.55% to 24.52 in the homebuilder's shares. The stock remains in buy range from a 23.72 cup-with-handle entry.FANG stock Netflix (NFLX) had its price target hiked to 185 from 175 ahead of the video streamer's Q2 earnings results July 17. The price target represents about a 16% premium to Wednesday's closing price. The social media firm was upgraded to buy from neutral.Within the IBD 50, laser maker Coherent (COHR) traded 4% higher, while PayPal (PYPL) continued to add gains, up nearly 1%, to its recent breakout. PayPal broke out of a flat base with a 55.24 buy point on July 10.On the downside, China-education stock New Oriental Education (EDU) slid nearly 2%% as it continues to build a base.RELATED:FANG Stocks News & Quotes: Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, GoogleNetflix Price Target Hiked; Snap 'Compelling'; AT&T, Seagate DowngradedDow Jones industrial average And Dow Stocks: News And AnalysisRetail & E-Commerce News And Stocks To WatchTarget Pops On Positive Same-Store Sales, Earnings Guidance

Stocks wrestled to a healthy finish Thursday in a session where early gains were dented by Senate testimony from Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen.XThe Dow Jones industrial average slimmed to a 0.1% gain, after climbing almost 0.2% in late trade.  The S&P 500 and Nasdaq ended up 0.2% each.  Small caps posted a weak session, with Russell 2000 futures ending only slightly below the break-even line.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 dropped hard just after 10 a.m. ET, during the first half hour of the Fed chair's Senate testimony Thursday. The S&P 500 rallied back to retake its early-morning high. The Nasdaq posted its high of the day just ahead of Yellen's testimony.The day's economic data had a mixed effect on trade, including a more slight-than-expected drop in weekly unemployment claims and a smaller-than-forecast increase in core producer prices for June.Thursday's action left the Nasdaq composite ahead nearly 2% for the week and tracking toward its best weekly finish since late May.  The S&P 500 was up 0.9% and the Dow Jones industrial average held a 0.6% gain.Six of the 10 strongest gains among industries came from retail groups, with department stores and auto parts chains leading the procession.Target (TGT) appeared to launch the retail rally, rising nearly 5% after boosting its second-quarter same-store-sales and earnings guidance, based on strong April and May traffic. Dillards (DDS), Kohl's (KSS) and J.C. Penney (JCP) all surged 5% or more. Wal-Mart (WMT) climbed 1.5% to lead the Dow industrials.Apple (AAPL) was hot on Wal-Mart's heels, up 1.4% as it reached to test resistance at its 10-week moving average. The stock has been trading below that line since a heavy-volume drop on June 9.Among auto parts retailers, AutoZone (AZO) and Advanced Auto Parts (AAP) popped 3%, while O'Reilly Auto Parts (ORLY) thrashed out a 5% advance.Automakers, on the other hand, posted one of the day's two worst declines among industry groups. Tesla (TSLA) underwrote that decline, tumbling 2% in weak trade. The stock is in its second week below its 10-week moving average, ending 17% below its June 23 high.Applied OptoElectronics (AAOI) sprung up 7% and triggered a rally in fiber-optic plays after preannouncing June-quarter earnings and revenue above analyst expectations. The stock spiked to new highs, but its consolidation was too short to be a cup base and too deep for a flat-base pattern, so offered no valid buy point.Fiber-optic peer Lumentum Holdings (LITE) bolted 6% higher, gaining volume support on its rebound from its 10-week moving average.RELATED:For Vacation, Watch These Travel Stocks: Investing Action PlanNetflix Earnings Power Underappreciated, Gets Price Target HikeFiber Stocks Rally As Applied Opto Preannounces Q2 BeatIs Apple Basing Now? And Is That Good For Stocks?

The Dow Jones industrial average continued its win streak, setting record highs for 10 straight sessions through Thursday. President Trump gave more tax hints. Tesla (TSLA) sold off following its Q4 report, while Dow retailers Home Depot (HD) and Wal-Mart (WMT) rallied on earnings. Facebook (FB) took more steps to combat Snapchat, whose parent Snap is about to price its IPO.The Dow Jones industrial average has risen for 11 straight sessions, its longest win streak in decades, helped by Wal-Mart and Home Depot. The S&P 500 index edged higher while the Nasdaq composite rose fractionally despite postearnings sell-offs such as Tesla and Weibo (WB).Restaurant earnings woes slammed the sector. Nvidia (NVDA) closed below its 50-day line for the first time in more than a year. President Trump said he backs "some sort" of border tax, but a top aide said the White House opposes the House GOP version. Infrastructure stocks fell on a report that Trump won't push a big public works bill until 2018.RELATED:Tesla reported a wider-than-expected adjusted loss while revenue rose 88% to $2.28 billion, beating the consensus. But investors looked ahead. Tesla said plans for its Model 3 sedan are on track to start limited vehicle production in July and predicts that it will deliver 47,000 to 50,000 Model S and Model X cars in the first half of this year. But Elon Musk said getting the Model 3 launched will put Tesla's cash levels "close to the edge," suggesting a capital raise would be prudent. Tesla shares tumbled 6.4% on Thursday, dropping below its recent breakout.RELATED:Facebook stock hit a record high as as the social networking giant continued to ape upstart Snapchat's features as Snapchat's parent is on the verge of its IPO. Facebook's WhatsApp messaging service began offer a service much like Snapchat Stories. Facebook's photo-sharing app, Instagram Stories, launched last August and already has 150 million users, about as many as Snapchat has. Facebook also is launching Stories on its main app in some countries.Facebook has continued to rally since Snap (SNAP) released its S-1 filing detailing its financials and IPO plans on Feb. 2. Snap, expected to launch next week, seeks to raise $3 billion, valuing the company at 18.5 billion to $22.2 billion.RELATED:Mobileye (MBLY) reported faster earnings and revenue growth Wednesday that topped fourth-quarter expectations, sending shares higher.Mobileye, a leading developer of advanced driver-assistance technology, reported that revenue grew 46% vs. a year earlier, to $104.6 million, beating the consensus estimate of $96.4 million. Earnings per share minus items rose 47%, to 22 cents, beating views for 20 cents. That ended a four-quarter string of decelerating EPS and sales growth.Mobileye pared gains Friday as short-seller Citron Research once again targeted the stock, saying it no longer has a tech edge over rivals.RELATED:The home-improvement retailer breezed past fourth-quarter estimates, citing "a healthy housing market and strong customer demand." Home Depot (HD) also announced a big payout hike and buyback. Home Depot shares rose more than 2% for the week, hitting fresh all-time highs.RELATED:Wal-Mart earnings fell, but not as much as feared. Revenue just missed estimates, but U.S. same-store sales were solid while online sales jumped 29%. Wal-Mart's move this quarter to offer free two-day shipping for $35 minimum orders forced Amazon.com (AMZN) to partly follow suit. Meanwhile, Macy's (M) and Kohl's (KSS) also reported declining profit and revenue, while Nordstrom (JWN) posted higher results, but all three also missed sales targets despite solid e-commerce gains. J.C. Penney (JCP), which had mixed Q4 results as well, said it would close 130-140 stores in the next few months. Conflicting reports on President Trump's position on a border tax, which retailers opposes, also affected retail shares.RELATED:Jack in the Box (JACK) and Texas Roadhouse (TXRH) turned out earnings that missed Wall Street expectations, while results from Papa John's (PZZA) and Cheesecake Factory (CAKE) were mixed. Shares, largely, got torched. The results come amid concerns about weak restaurant traffic this year as things like cheaper groceries offer more incentive to eat in.RELATED:BHP Billiton (BHP) earned $3.244 billion in underlying six-month profit, a 687% year-over-year gain, thanks to higher prices for the metal ore and crude oil that it produces. Revenue jumped 20% to $18.8 billion. BHP also raised its interim dividend by 150% vs. a year earlier, to 40 cents a share. Vale (VALE) swung to a profit that missed views, but investors cheered further governance moves to reduce the influence of the Brazilian government. But BHP and Vale shares fell as a report that Trump may delay an infrastructure bill until 2018 hit iron and copper prices. Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) tumbled as it slashed forecasts amid a standoff with Indonesia over exports from the world's No. 2 copper mine.RELATED:Anglo-Dutch consumer and food products giant Unilever (UN) initiated a review to accelerate value after in the wake of rejecting a $143 billion merger offer from Kraft Heinz (KHC), which pulled its bid on Sunday, Feb. 19. Unilever could divest some areas, speed up cost cutting or make its own acquisition. Colgate Palmolive (CL) is among the consumer or food products makers that are possible targets. Unilever and Kraft fell during the week from their Feb. 17 bid news spike to record highs, but kept much of that gain.RELATED:Oil prices rose to their highest close in 19 months on Thursday on a smaller-than-expected U.S. inventory gain. But U.S. crude production topped 9 million barrels per day for the first time in 10 months. Gasoline stockpiles fell. OPEC wants compliance to its output deal, currently at a relatively high 90%, to rise even higher. Continental Resources (CLR) and Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO) reported mixed Q4 results, while Oasis Petroleum (OAS) and Rice Energy (RICE) beat, Apache (APA) missed, and U.S. Silica (SLCA) revenue beat.RELATED:Weibo, known as China's Twitter, reported strong earnings and revenue growth on brisk user gains, with guidance also bullish. But shares, which had been at record highs, tumbled 16% on Thursday, crashing below a buy point. Sina, which owns a majority stake in Weibo, plunged 13% Thursday despite its own view-topping results. Alibaba (BABA) pulled back after trying to break out. Mobile gaming giant NetEase (NTES) and dating site Momo (MOMO) retreated, but remain well above buy points. Baidu (BIDU) fell Friday after reporting mixed results.RELATED:Verizon (VZ) agreed to pay $4.48 billion for core operations of Yahoo (YHOO), $350 million less than the $4.83 billion original price announced in July. That comes after Yahoo revealed two massive hacks that took place years ago. Also, Verizon and Altaba, which is what the rest of Yahoo will rename itself, will split breach-related liabilities 50-50. Altaba will hold Yahoo's sizable holdings in Alibaba and Yahoo Japan.RELATED:Acacia Communications earned 94 cents excluding various items on revenue of $142.4 million, both topping Q4 estimates. But the maker of gear for high-speed networks gave Q1 EPS and sales guidance that are well below the consensus. Acacia (ACIA) tumbled Friday. But Applied Optoelectronics (AAOI), which is another optical play, boomed Friday on its quarterly results.

The stock market looked to continue its winning ways after rebounding from early trading weakness.After initial declines, all three major indexes have now moved 0.2% higher through midday trading.Despite a hawkish tone from Fed Chair Janet Yellen, stocks have rebounded higher, setting new records, while financial stocks added to recent gains.Volume was tracking higher across both exchanges vs. the same time Monday.Within the Dow Jones industrial average, Goldman Sachs (GS) and JP Morgan (JPM) rose more than 1%. Nike (NKE) also moved up about 1%, reaching five-month highs.Apple (AAPL) advanced 1% as the stock continued to impress following its earnings release several weeks ago. Shares are now up 14% from its 118.12 cup-with-handle entry.Among U.S. automakers, General Motors (GM) soared more than 4% to reclaim its 50-day line after PSA Group, parent company of Peugot, announced it was in talks with General Motors to acquire its struggling Opel division. GM's Opel division includes its British Vauxhall brand.After making a bid for record highs, Tesla (TSLA) gave back part of its early gains. After being up as much as 2.4%, the stock settled up 0.8%. During its five-day winning streak, the electric-auto maker has risen 10%. The stock is extended from its 258.56 cup-with-handle entry.Retailers were moving up nicely in the stock market today after being consistent underperformers due to the disappointing holiday season.Best Buy (BBY) looked to reclaim its 50-day line after a 3.2% move higher. The retailer has been consolidating since December 2016.Kohl's (KSS) rose 3% as it looked to regain its 200-day line, which it lost when it gapped down on Jan. 5 following its dismal holiday sales announcement.On the downside, the energy sector was lagging the general market.Despite a rise in the price of crude oil, which is up 0.4%, oil and gas stocks found themselves at the bottom of the S&P 500's performers.Apache (APA) and Noble Energy (NBL) were two of the biggest losers, each falling more than 3%.Apache is consolidating below its 200-day line, while Noble reversed hard following its earning release after the bell on Monday.RELATED:GM Jumps On Talks To Sell European Unit Opel To PeugotTesla Stock Continues Drive Toward All-Time HighDow Stocks JPMorgan, Goldman Rise As Fed Signals More Hawkishness

Twitter (TWTR) is seeing an increase in analyst downgrades after revenue stalled in Q4. Nvidia (NVDA) got a higher price target after its latest blistering earnings report. Wall Street also issued new ratings or price targets on Ford Motor (F), Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS), Nordstrom and Costco Wholesale (COST).Cowen and Raymond James both downgraded the social media network to underperform, while UBS and Citigroup cut Twitter to a sell. Deutsche Bank merely downgraded the stock to hold. Twitter's mixed fourth-quarter results and weak guidance disappointed investors, sending shares down over 12% Thursday.Twitter fell 5% to close at 15.58 in the stock market today, hitting its lowest levels since late June.RELATED:Mizuho, which has a buy rating on Nvidia, bumped up its price target to 130 from 115.The graphics chipmaker that easily topped analyst forecasts on the top and bottom lines late Thursday but offered up current-quarter guidance that were merely in line with expectations.Shares initially popped to 120.70, making its second brief foray this week over a 120.03 buy point. But the stock reversed to close down 2.4% to 113.62.RELATED:Jefferies upgraded Ford's stock to hold.Peer General Motors (GM) came out ahead of Q4 views and reaffirmed previously announced strong full-year profit outlook.Automakers have recently faced pressure from President Trump over keeping manufacturing and jobs in the U.S.Ford rose 1% to 12.51.RELATED:Susquehanna initiated coverage of all three department stores with a neutral rating.Department stores have had enough of a hard time amid a challenging retail environment, but Nordstrom got a surprise Trump bump after the President attacked the company on Twitter for no longer carrying his daughter's branded goods. Retailers in general are rallying on hopes that Trump's tax plan may not include a GOP border-adjustment tax that would sock merchants.Macy's, Nordstrom and Kohl's 1.5% initially rallied, but reversed to finish down 1.2%, 1.2% and 0.1%, respectively.RELATED:IBD's TAKE: Malls have been forced to ramp up the drama in the age of Amazon (AMZN). Here's what that looks like.But Susquehanna handed the membership warehouse a positive rating. Costco has been outperforming its retail peers, and in January logged its best same-store sales results in over two years.Shares rose 0.6% after hitting a record high Thursday.RELATED:

J.C. Penney (JCP) and Nike (NKE) have joined forces to launch Nike "brand shop environments" in more than 600 J.C. Penney stores, the department store chain said Tuesday.The linkup between the midlevel department store company and major sports apparel brand pits them directly against another similar duo. Under Armour (UAA) announced last July a move to roll out products at around 600 Kohl's (KSS) locations starting early this year.On the surface, the most notable difference in the two alliances appears to be the gender of their target consumers.The 500 sq. ft. Nike shop-in-shops, which are now available, have been placed in a "prominent location within the men's department," said J.C. Penney, and will feature basketball, training and running product areas. The details found in the press release appeared primarily geared toward men's products, though the company said "similar visual elements are available in select stores for women and kids."Meanwhile, Under Armour Chief Executive Kevin Plank acknowledged last year that the majority of Kohl's customers are women shoppers."We think Kohl's is a great evolution for us," said Plank in Under Armour's second-quarter call in late July, adding he thinks there's "a big opportunity" in the women's market.IBD's TAKE: What's in store for American shoppers? A "reckoning," says one expert.The move comes at a time when athletic wear remains popular but department stores have largely been struggling to keep abreast of Amazon.com (AMZN) and other online shopping destinations.A brief postelection rally for department stores soon gave way to a downswing that was further weighed down by weak holiday sales figures. Macy's (M), Nordstrom (JWN), Kohl's, J.C. Penney have all been trading well below their key 50-day and 200-day moving averages.But shares of J.C. Penney advanced 2.7% on the stock market today, as retailers and apparel makers generally rallied following President-elect Trump's negative comments about a House GOP plan to tax imports. Nike climbed 1.4% and Kohl's 1.45%. Under Armour closed up 0.2%.RELATED:Wal-Mart, Best Buy, Apple Rally After Trump Pans GOP Border Adjustment TaxRetailers Face 2017 'Reckoning,' More 'Sad Malls' As Amazon Keeps Booming

Upscale jeweler Tiffany (TIF) reported "somewhat lower" than expected November-December sales, citing lower consumer spending and a sharp drop in sales at its flagship New York store in part due to protests and security at Trump Tower following the election.Global sales rose 0.5% in the last two months of the year, with worldwide same-store sales down 2%, or 1% excluding currency effects. Comps in the Americas sank 4%. Sales at the Fifth Avenue store tumbled 14%, "at least partly to post-election traffic disruptions," Tiffany said. Trump Tower is located right next door to Tiffany's flagship location.Tiffany had warned in November that post-election disruptions could hurt sales. A strong dollar also can weigh on tourism sales at the flagship store.European comps sank 11%, while Japan comps shot up 21%.Tiffany sees GAAP and non-GAAP earnings falling "no more" than a mid-single-digit percentage. Wall Street had seen only a 1% dip to $1.44 a share.Shares of Tiffany fell 2.5% to 79.90 on the stock market today after falling as low as 78.57, briefly undercutting their 50-day line. The stock hit 85.44 on Dec. 8, its highest level since August 2015.The company follows a slew of retailers, including mall-base jeweler Signet Jewelers (SIG) and department store giants Kohl's (KSS) and Macy's (M), despite economic optimism hitting a 10-year high as customers shift to online retailers such as Amazon (AMZN).Signet shares rose 0.5% Tuesday to 81.15 after tumbling 8.4% last week and 6.4% in the week before that.Tiffany named Reed Krakoff to the new position of chief artistic officer. Krakoff, who has held senior roles at Coach (COH) and Ralph Lauren (RL), will direct design for its brand jewelry and luxury accessories.RELATED:Wal-Mart, Best Buy, Apple Rally After Trump Pans GOP Border Adjustment TaxRetail Sales Rise 0.6% As Amazon, Autos LeadAmazon Plants A 'We're Hiring' Sign To Reach 100,000 New JobsJCPenney Joins Macy's, Kohl's With Weak Holiday Sales

Nike (NKE) shares are falling Thursday after the No. 1 sports apparel brand said it expects to cut about 2% of its global workforce as it implements leadership and organization changes. Separately, Under Armour (UAA) got an estimate cut as one analyst says stores are "likely canceling" product orders.The changes are meant to "streamline and speed up strategic execution," said Nike in a press release. Its new "consumer direct offense" targets a dozen cities — New York, London, Shanghai, Beijing, Los Angeles, Tokyo, Paris, Berlin, Mexico City, Barcelona, Seoul, and Milan — that are seen accounting for over 80% of its growth through 2020.Nike, a Dow Jones industrial average component, has had its eyes set on reaching $50 billion in revenue by the end of fiscal 2020, with North America making up 40% of that target.Nike shares fell 3.2% to 52.90 on the stock market today, falling back below their 50-day and 200-day moving averages.Nike had more than 70,000 employees at the end of fiscal 2016.Aside from the job cuts, Thursday's announcement includes shuffling around of leadership positions and the creation of new segments.Its previously announced "triple double" strategy aims to halve the product-creation cycle, and the company said Thursday that its head of product and merchandising, Michael Spillane, will become President of Categories and Product, a new unit, to "supercharge this faster pipeline."More resources will be dedicated to running, basketball, Nike sportswear, men's and women's training, soccer and young athletes, the "categories with the highest potential to fuel growth."Its new Nike Direct unit marries its website, direct-to-consumer retail and Nike+ digital offerings.IBD'S TAKE: This follows a recent change in Nike's "futures" reporting that indicated a shift in its mix of retail and e-commerce sales: That Nike Metric That Sank Shares? Stop Looking At It, Says NikeAs part of the changes, the company will start divvying up its financial reporting into four geographic areas — North America, Europe, Middle East and Africa (EMEA), Greater China and Asia-Pacific and Latin America (APLA) — down from six.Meanwhile, Susquehanna reduced its Under Armour profit and sales estimates for fiscal 2017 and 2018 on expectations that stores such as Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS), Hibbett (HIBB), Academy, Modell's and Scheel's "will shrink their exposure to Under Armour in response to the poor product segmentation and the little progress in fixing the problem."Analyst Sam Poser said it's "becoming clear" that sales of Under Armour products at Kohl's (KSS), DSW (DSW) and Famous Footwear won't be enough to offset lost sales from shuttered sports-apparel retailers, and that stores are beginning to promote Under Armour items to price-match Kohl's, spurring concerns of more promotional activity."There is also little to no progress being made by UAA to create product that resonates from a fashion perspective," added Poser.Under Armour shares fell 4.4% to 21.71.Nike, however, segments its items "well enough that its customers that shop at (Dick's) have no interest in the product at (Kohl's), regardless of the price, and the Nike brand remains unscathed," he said.Adidas (ADDYY), which has revived its brand in the U.S., fell 3.1% to 96.91, backing away from a potential buy point of 102.09. Adidas lost two court rulings in its bid to block Skechers (SKX) from selling its Mega-Blade children's shoes. Skechers shares dipped 0.1%.RELATED:Under Armour Near 5-Month High, Nike Extends Rally After NBA WinUnder Armour Loss Less Than Feared; Stock Clears Key HurdleNike, Adidas Have This 'Major Roadblock' Against Amazon

Like a pro athlete, Nike (NKE) knows that it needs to tweak its strategy from time to time to stay competitive.XOn its fourth-quarter earnings call on Thursday, Wall Street will likely be looking for more commentary on the athletic footwear and apparel maker's new consumer-focused initiatives intended to keep it in sync with a digitally driven retail environment and ahead of rivals Adidas (ADDYY) and Under Armour (UAA). Nike's recent sales arrangement with Amazon (AMZN)? Expect questions about that too.For the quarter, Wall Street expects flat year-over-year per-share earnings of 49 cents on 4.5% revenue growth to $8.61 billion, according to Zacks Investment Research. That would mark a second flat Q4 for EPS and a slight slowdown in sales growth.The results will come roughly two weeks after Nike announced a new "consumer direct offense" alignment. That effort reorganizes Nike's leadership and geographic structure and tightens its focus on a dozen key cities across the world that are expected to account for 80% of its projected growth through 2020.Part of Nike's new game plan also involves what it calls a "triple double" goal to double innovation, speed to market and direct engagement with customers. The plan also includes laying off 2% of its global workforce. Nike shares fell more than 3% on June 15, the day of the news.Nike and other major athletic apparel and footwear brands are all developing manufacturing and supply-chain technologies to get on-trend products on shelves faster. Under Armour this week also announced a leadership shuffle of its own, reviving its COO position.The sluggish retail environment has raised questions about how and where individual brands will sell their products, as brick-and-mortar stores like Macy's (M) and J.C. Penney (JCP) struggle to shore up store traffic amid competition from Amazon and off-price chains.Nike will reportedly sell footwear directly on Amazon in an attempt to combat the sale of knockoff goods at the e-commerce giant. That could spell trouble for J.C. Penney and Kohl's (KSS), Gordon Haskett analyst Charles Grom said last week.Shares of Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) and Foot Locker (FL) immediately took a hit on news of a possible Nike-Amazon team-up — perhaps not without reason. Nike, Adidas, Hanesbrands (HBI)-owned Hanes and Under Armour are the most frequently bought brands on Amazon, Morgan Stanley said in April.As Nike dials down the emphasis on its self-created "futures orders" — a metric designed to reflect retailer demand — it is dialing up its own in-house manufacturing and selling capabilities, with aims to halve its product-creation cycle and streamline its brick-and-mortar and online retail experiences.Still, Cowen this month trimmed its price target on Nike to 53 from 54 on increased promotional activity amid its rivalry with Adidas and Under Armour, and JPMorgan downgraded the stock to neutral from overweight.Morgan Stanley analyst Jay Sole said earlier this month that the market is expecting Nike to guide fiscal 2018 profit below consensus for $2.52 per share — Zacks currently puts consensus at $2.44 — but that those expectations have already been priced into the stock. He has an equal-weight rating on the stock.Given "poor" sentiment and high short interest in Nike, Sole sees bulls snapping up shares of the athletic brand after the market digests the company's full-year guidance on Thursday.Nike shares closed up 0.8% at 53.36 on the stock market today, hitting resistance on the underside of their converging 50-day and 200-day lines. The stock is up less than 5% so far in calendar 2017, underperforming the S&P 500. Under Armour reversed lower to finish down 0.6%, and Amazon added 1.4%.RELATED:Under Armour Names New COO, Announces ReorganizationHere's The Latest Group Having An Amazon-Induced Anxiety AttackNike To Shrink Workforce As Stores Seen 'Canceling' Under ArmourNike, Adidas Have This 'Major Roadblock' Against Amazon

XThe Nordstrom (JWN) family is exploring the possibility of a "'going private transaction' involving the acquisition by the Group of 100% of the outstanding shares of common stock of the Company," said the company in an official statement.Nordstrom's board has assembled a special committee of independent directors to act on behalf of the department store chain regarding the exploration, it said.Shares jumped as much as 18% in morning trade on the stock market today but faded to close up 10.3% at 44.64, dropping back below their 50-day average. Other department stores reversed lower after early rallies, with Macy's (M) down 0.2%, Kohl's (KSS) 2.3% and J.C. Penney (JCP) 4.8%.Department stores have suffered in recent years as fast fashion options like Forever 21 proliferate and e-commerce giant Amazon (AMZN) continues to encroach on brick-and-mortar turf.Macy's warned on Tuesday that gross margins would be worse than projected in February, sending its shares and those of Kohl's, J.C. Penney and Nordstrom sharply lower.Separately Thursday, Canada's Hudson's Bay, which also owns Saks Fifth Avenue, announced late Thursday that it will cut 2,000 jobs in North America, including cuts announced in February. Hudson's Bay trades in Toronto but not in the U.S.Amazon rose 20 cents to 1,010.27, near record highs.RELATED:Macy's Triggers New Retail Rout On Gross Margins WarningDeath Stalks Retail Stocks, But Hope Lives OnMacy's Shocker, Other Results Trigger Broad Retail RoutMacy's Doesn't Know How To Fix Its Stores, Hopes Something Will Work

XFor the second time in less than a month, Macy's (M) triggered a big sell-off in department store stocks, after warning on Tuesday that gross margins would be worse than those forecast in February.During the struggling retailer's investor meeting, CFO Karen Hoguet said that full-year gross margin was on pace to come in 60 to 80 basis points lower than margins last year, as Macy's struggles to move inventory from its shelves, according to reports.Macy's tumbled 8.2% to 21.90, crashing to the lowest since February 2011. Kohl's (KSS) lost 5.75%, hitting its worst levels since June 2016. J.C. Penney (JCP) retreated 4%. Nordstrom (JWN) fell 3.7% to its lowest close in 11 months.Sears Holdings (SHLD), which faces "going concern" issues, sank 2.5%.The darker forecast follows another quarter of reckoning for physical stores, as more people shop online, especially at Amazon (AMZN).Macy's bleak Q1 earnings report and guidance last month spurred a big drop in department stores and other retailers, adding to concerns that brick-and-mortar chains can't combat the massive shift in how people shop.Along with Amazon and other e-commerce sites, stores like Macy's, Kohl's, J.C. Penney and Sears have also been gutted by off-price retailers and fast-fashion.During the investor day meeting, Macy's said cost cuts and managing its mix of owned vs. leased properties would help margins in the future.RELATED:Death Stalks Retail Stocks, But Hope Lives OnMacy's Shocker, Other Results Trigger Broad Retail RoutMacy's Doesn't Know How To Fix Its Stores, Hopes Something Will WorkAmazon's New Wal-Mart Assault: Prime Cut For Government-Aid Recipients

Shares of Sears Canada (SRSC) crashed Wednesday following reports that the ailing retailer could be headed for liquidation after moving to seek protection from creditors, deepening the wounds suffered by brick-and-mortar chains as Amazon.com (AMZN) continues to pluck customers from malls.Sears Canada could have trouble selling off its locations to a single purchaser, as many of those locations are in lower-tier shopping centers, Bloomberg said.Sears Canada earlier this month raised "significant doubt" over its ability to continue operating after struggling to obtain sufficient financing. Meanwhile, Sears Holdings (SHLD), which owns 12% of Sears Canada, warned in March that "substantial doubt" existed over whether it could survive.Sears Canada shares tumbled nearly 20% to 47 cents on the stock market today. Sears Holdings dropped 5.4% to 6.43. J.C. Penney (JCP) fell 5.7%, Dillard's (DDS) dropped 2.3% and Kohl's (KSS) lost 1.3%. Mid-tier Macy's (M) slid 2.3% while upscale Nordstrom (JWN) edged down 0.3% after both sold off Tuesday on news that Amazon will start a service that allows customers to receive clothes at home and try them on before buying them.IBD'S TAKE: Running a retailer in recent years has become a lot more about managing real estate. Macy's is even looking at how to rework its parking lots.A liquidation of Sears Canada would follow Target's (TGT) plans, announced in 2015, to exit Canada, and it would join a growing list of retailers in bankruptcy or on the brink.In March, discount department-store chain Gordmans Stores filed for bankruptcy with plans to liquidate. Wet Seal, BCBG Maxzria and Payless ShoeSource have filed for bankruptcy in recent months as well.In April, women's apparel chain Bebe (BEBE) said it would close all its stores by the end of May to become an online-only retailer, and Vince (VNCE) said it had "substantial doubt about the company's ability to continue" over leverage debt ratio concerns.Sears Canada's potential move toward creditor protection would also come as Sears' legal disputes with suppliers increasingly occur out in the open.Sears Holdings has sued two suppliers of Craftsman tools in the past two months over their agreements to deliver products to the retailer. Sears this month settled with the first of those companies, One World, which Sears CEO Eddie Lampert said had tried to "embarrass us in the media to force us to let them out of their contract."RELATED:Amazon-Whole Foods Merger Could Be 'Category Killer' For Food, EateriesWhat Amazon's Whole Foods Deal Means For RetailMacy's Doesn't Know How To Fix Its Stores, Hopes Something Will Work

Under Armour (UAA) shares are in a tailspin Tuesday after fourth-quarter earnings disappointed and the athletic apparel brand said CFO Chip Molloy is stepping down "due to personal reasons."During the key holiday shopping season, the Nike (NKE) rival logged a penny's profit decline from the prior-year to 23 cents a share on 12% revenue growth to $1.308 billion, the weakest gain in eight years. North American sales grew just 6% while international revenue (16% of the total) jumped 55%.Analysts had expected a 4% EPS rise to 25 cents with sales up 20% to $1.409 billion."Numerous challenges and disruptions in North American retail tempered our fourth quarter results," said Kevin Plank, Under Armour Chairman and CEO, in a statement.The quarter is prompting something of a reset — at least of Plank's well-known whiteboard. He scrubbed the board clean of his maxims and motivational phrases (most notably "Don't forget to sell shirts and shoes") and replaced it with "Keep Under Armour simple," he said during the earnings call.For 2017, management expects net revenue to rise 11%-12% to reach nearly $5.4 billion, well below analyst views for $6.05 billion. Along with this "tempered" sales growth, "strategic investments" will lead to a drop in operating income.Shares crashed nearly 26% to 21.49 in the stock market today, setting a three-year low. Under Armour is on track for its worst one-day stock loss since it came public in 2005.The guidance left one analyst wondering if the brand might be struggling more than it is letting on."The revenue guidance is peculiar given the rollout into Kohl's (KSS)," wrote Susquehanna's Sam Poser, who downgraded the stock to neutral from positive. "However, the decision to go to the moderate channel may have been more reactive than we had previously thought."Athletic footwear stocks have largely been having a tough go of it for the last year. Under Armour, Nike and Skechers (SKX) all posted double-digit share-price declines in 2016 amid a tough consumer environment. NPD Group said Monday that the athletic footwear industry grew a below-average 3% in 2016, with slight declines during the holiday quarter as the bankruptcies of Sports Authority and Sport Chalet.Nike stock fell 0.3% intraday, but rebounded from morning lows to close back above its 50-day line. Skechers rose 0.8% after undercutting its 50-day intraday.And as retro and classic trends rule the sneaker set, Under Armour is acknowledging that the brand does not have as much fashion cred as it could."We need to become more fashionable with the products that are out there," said Plank during the call. He said the company had been counting on core basics, but today's consumer "frankly has more options" from good brands that are discounting their prices, he said."The consumer expects more today, he later added.Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy, who downgraded the stock from overweight to neutral, noted the slowdown."By segment, apparel grew only 7% — well below the 17% growth rate we anticipated and while footwear was still a healthy 36%, we see the slowing apparel as a significant concern to the brand given the importance of this category," she wrote.But Plank, predictably, still sounded bullish on the future, particularly the China and womenswear markets."Our eyes are wide open and we're ready to run in 2017 and beyond," he said.When Molloy steps down, senior VP David Bergman will take over as acting CFO on Feb. 3, said Under Armour.RELATED:Spring Retail Playoffs: J.C. Penney-Nike Vs. Kohl's-Under ArmourDow Dog Nike Comes Out Swinging; Bullish On North America, BasketballUnder Armour Dives On Growth Targets; Execs Vow To Invest 'Aggressively'

With Amazon.com (AMZN) breathing down its neck, Wal-Mart (WMT) has reorganized its e-commerce unit and assigned new executive positions.The changes are meant to make Wal-Mart more "customer-centric," says a report from Bloomberg. Wal-Mart is investing heavily in online operations. It bought e-commerce startup Jet.com for $3.3 billion in September. The founder of Jet.com, Marc Lore, is now CEO of Wal-Mart's e-commerce operation.The company is streamlining its web team so that it can better serve customers when they shop online, via smartphones or in stores, according to a Wal-Mart memo obtained by Bloomberg.Amazon has put increased pressure on Wal-Mart in fields like food and grocery and apparel. And last month, Amazon announced Amazon Go, a high-tech convenience store in Seattle, where Amazon is based. The 1,800-square-foot store is in beta-testing for now; it's slated to open to all in early 2017. Amazon Go takes dead aim at the physical-store world and poses an increasing threat to Wal-Mart and others.Amazon stock rose 0.44% to 817.24 in the stock market today, and it's risen all but one trading day in 2017. Wal-Mart stock fell 1.2% to 67.13.IBD'S TAKE: In addition to its bold e-commerce play, Amazon is leading the market in cloud computing services with other plans to spread its tentacles far and wide.The threat of Amazon is putting the squeeze on Wal-Mart and other big retailers such as Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS) and Sears (SHLD), and the company looks to be getting larger. On Thursday, Amazon said it would boost its full-time U.S.-based workforce by 100,000, aiming to reach 280,000 jobs by mid-2018. Amazon employed 30,000 in 2011.Amazon said many of the new jobs will be in fulfillment centers that have been announced over the past several months and are currently under construction in Texas, California, Florida, New Jersey and other states. Amazon delivered more than 2 billion packages for independent merchants in 2016, more than double its 2015 tally.But a report by Pacific Crest Securities says the new hires could also be part of Amazon's push to accelerate efforts to build physical stores."Amazon will also add nonfulfillment center jobs, but we think that still leaves a significant and unexplained gap," the Pacific Crest report said. "We believe that this could be explained by an accelerated rollout of physical stores. In particular, we think that a potential grocery pickup concept looks particularly promising."Already this year, Macy's has detailed plans to shutter 68 stores and cut more than 10,000 jobs. It plans to close a total of 100 locations. Macy's and Kohl's both slashed holiday-quarter earnings estimates after their same-store sales for November-December fell 2.1%.Sears said it would close another 150 Sears and Kmart stores. The Limited said it would close all 250 of its stores, and ax 4,000 jobs, as it moves its entire operation online.RELATED: Amazon Spreads Its Tentacles Far Beyond 'World's Biggest Bookstore'Amazon's Latest Perk For Prime Members? 5% Back Visa CardAmazon's Next Big Growth Opportunity Could Be ApparelAmazon: Still The E-Commerce Elephant In The Retail Room?

Here's your weekly Investing Action Plan: what you need to know as an investor for the coming week. Tech darlings Facebook (FB), Apple (AAPL) and Amazon (AMZN) report earnings, while Federal Reserve policymakers mull interest rates again, and fresh job data provide new clues on how much inflationary pressure the U.S. economy is seeing. Oil majors Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Royal…

Retail sales rose 0.6% in December and 0.2% excluding autos, as the holiday shopping season ended on a so-so note.Wall Street expected a 0.7% monthly bump, or 0.5% excluding auto sales. November sales were revised to a 0.2 % rise and 0.3% excluding autos.Stocks weakened slightly after the report.The 2.4% gain in auto sales came as strong December results from General Motors (GM) helped lift industry sales to an 18.4 million annual pace. General Motors, which reported a 10% year-over-year U.S. gain, gave a bullish forecast for 2017 earnings this week.Sales at nonstore retailers led by Amazon (AMZN) jumped 1.3% in December and 13.2% from a year ago. Amazon was seen as grabbing a share of e-commerce holiday sales growth. Meanwhile, the shift away from mall clobbers department stores including Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS) and Sears (SHLD). Amazon said Thursday that it will add 100,000 full-time jobs in the U.S. by mid-2018. Meanwhile, Macy's and Sears announced store closures after Macy's and Kohl's slashed earnings forecasts as both reported November-December comps fall 2.1% vs. a year earlier.General merchandise sales fell 0.5%, with the department store category down 0.6% in December and 8.4% from a year ago.

The IBD/TIPP Economic Optimism Index rose in January after surging at the end of 2016, as enthusiasm following Donald Trump's election continues to build into the new year.The Economic Optimism Index climbed 0.8 point in January to 55.6, just below the November 2006 peak of 55.7. That followed December's 3.4-point jump in the wake of the presidential election. That 8.2% gain over two months almost exactly matches the 8.3% rally in the Dow Jones industrial average since Election Day through Tuesday. Not only is the stock rally fattening investor portfolios and 401(k) accounts, it's providing tangible evidence that ordinary Americans should feel more upbeat.It's not unusual for confidence to improve after an election, especially when the party in power changes hands. After a grueling campaign season, voters are relieved to move on and hopeful that Trump's agenda of tax cuts and deregulation can boost economic growth and their own finances. And while big businesses worry about Trump singling them out for criticism on Twitter, many Americans see a decisive leader working for them."Americans are hopeful that President-elect Donald Trump will deliver on his promises to boost U.S. employment and grow the economy," said Raghavan Mayur, president of TechnoMetrica, IBD's polling partner. "Since Mr. Trump's victory, various companies, such as Ford (F), Alibaba (BABA), and Softbank (SFTBY), have committed to creating jobs here and investing in U.S. production. Further, the stock market has hit record highs, and is inching closer to 20,000. These encouraging signs are why many Americans see a bright future for the U.S. economy under Trump."The warm feelings aren't universal, as Americans continue to see the economy via a partisan lens. Republicans and independents became slightly more optimistic after turning sharply upbeat last month after the election. But Democrats were slightly more pessimistic after their sentiment cratered in December.The Economic Optimism Index has three main subindexes. They all are much higher since the presidential election.Meanwhile, the Financial Related Stress Index fell to 52.2 from 56 in December and 58.3 in October. That's the lowest reading — meaning less financial stress — since the gauge began in December 2007, when the recession started.IBD'S TAKE: In his final month of office, Americans give President Obama poor marks on the economy and race relations, but say his presidency was a success, according to the IBD/TIPP Poll.Consumers aren't alone in feeling more confident. The NFIB's small business optimism index for December soared to its highest level since the end of 2004. A net 50% of small firms see the economy improving, vs. 12% in November and -7% in October. Homebuilders' confidence has hit a decade high even with mortgage rates jumping in recent months.As businesses become more willing to invest and expand, consumers may step up their spending, especially with wage gains picking up.But not all retailers will be winners.Amazon (AMZN) appears to have had a strong holiday season yet again. But Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS) slashed profit forecasts as they were among several brick-and-mortar chains — but not all — warning of grim holiday sales as shoppers made purchases at Amazon and other online stores. It's unclear what Macy's and other department stores can do to stop the slide.Meanwhile, General Motors (GM) on Tuesday gave a bullish 2017 earnings forecast after reporting a surprisingly strong 10% U.S. sales gain in December. Ford announced a special dividend Tuesday and sees "improved profitability" in 2018 after an investment-heavy 2017.The IBD/TIPP Poll surveyed 904 adults from Jan. 3-9 via live interviews. It has an margin of error of +/- 3.3 points.RELATED:Trump Bump: Small Business Optimism Soars To 12-Year HighGeneral Motors Soars To 21-Month High On Bullish Earnings ForecastAmazon: Still The E-Commerce Elephant In The Retail Room?JCPenney Joins Macy's, Kohl's With Weak Holiday SalesMore Holiday Winners, Losers: Maybe Amazon Didn't Ruin Everything?

This past week the Dow Jones industrials finally climbed over the wall of 20,000, nearly 18 years after it cracked the 10,000 barrier (in February 1999) and more than 50 years after it hit 1,000 in January 1966. That said, corrections in individual stocks and the market itself provide savvy traders a limited yet legitimate opportunity to profit from brief,…

JCPenney (JCP) said that same-store sales fell 0.8% in November and December, making it the latest department store giant to put up uninspiring holiday results as malls become increasingly barren and Amazon.com (AMZN)-led e-commerce thrives.Macy's (M) and Kohl's (KSS) late Wednesday cut profit forecasts due to tepid holiday sales, with both saying November-December comps slid 2.1%. Macy's also said it planned to slash 10,000 jobs as it closes 68 stores as part of a plan to shut 100 locations over time. The forecasts also came after Macy's in November expressed optimism about the holiday quarter.Meanwhile, Sears (SHLD) said this week that it would sell Craftsman to Stanley Black & Decker (SWK) and close 150 Kmart and Sears locations.JCPenney fell 3.7% to 7.57 in the stock market today after tumbling 7.2% on Thursday.The retailer said the first three weeks of November were "challenging," but that comps from the Thanksgiving week through the end of December were positive. Sluggish sales in women's apparel continued to weigh on the chain's results, JCPenney said.The picture was a brighter for appliances, jewelry, outerwear, boots, toys and Sephora beauty products. JCPenney's e-commerce division saw "double-digit growth," the company said, and it held to its EBITDA goal of $1 billion for fiscal 2016."As we prepare for a new fiscal year, our turnaround in profitability remains on track, and I am pleased that we expect to deliver our fourth consecutive quarter of positive operating profit," CEO Marvin Ellison said in a statement.IBD'S TAKE: As traditional and specialty retailers struggle amid the galactic expansion of Amazon, off-price retailers have done better. Burlington Stores, formerly known as Burlington Coat Factory, was among the few growth stories in retail. As retailers reel, Adobe (ADBE) this week reported that online holiday sales rose 11% to a record $91.7 billion. Meanwhile, the December jobs report showed that nonstore retailers reported a 5.5% employment gain over the past 12 months. While neither report named Amazon, other surveys suggested that it was grabbing a huge share of overall e-commerce sales.Amazon rose 2%, continuing to advance after clearing its 50-day moving average earlier in the week.Macy's dipped 0.1% Friday after crashing nearly 14% Thursday. Kohl's lost 1.4% following Thursday's 19% plunge. Sears retreated 8% after edging higher Thursday.RELATED:Christmas Meltdown: Macy's, Kohl's, Kors, Fossil, L Brands, OthersAmazon Effect: As Retail ETFs Struggle, Internet ETF Eyes A BreakoutAfter The Mall Doors Close, Analysts Cut Macy's, Kohl; Chipotle UpgradedRetailers Face 2017 'Reckoning,' More 'Sad Malls' As Amazon Keeps BoomingNordstorm's '1972' Warning Is Another Sign Of Dying MallsKate Spade Stock Jumps On Report It's Considering Sale

The stock market closed mixed Thursday, a fairly resilient performance amid weakness in financial and retail stocks.The Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.2%, even as several financial blue chips retreated about 1%, including American Express (AXP), Goldman Sachs (GS) and JPMorgan (JPM). The S&P 500 lost 0.1% and the Nasdaq composite picked up 0.2%, setting a new record close. Small caps lagged badly, with the Russell 2000 down more than 1%.The stock market held up relatively well even as bonds surged. The 10-year Treasury yield fell 8 basis points to 2.36%.In the stock market today, retailers were generally weak after Macy's (M) and Kohl's (KSS) late Wednesday cut earnings estimates, citing weak holiday sales. Kohl's crashed 19%. Macy's plunged 14%.Sears (SHLD) edged higher after the troubled retailer agreed to sell its Craftsman tool brand to Stanley Black & Decker (SWK) for about $900 million. Sears also announced plans to shutter 150 unprofitable Sears and Kmart stores.Amazon.com (AMZN) was a strong gainer in the Nasdaq 100, up 3.1%, closing above its 50-day line for the first time since its Oct. 27 earnings report.Netflix (NFLX) extended gains after Wednesday's low-volume breakout. Volume was a little better Thursday as shares rose nearly 2% to 131.81, hitting a record close. It's still in buy range from a 129.39 cup-with-handle buy point.Meanwhile, after a period of underperformance, China growth names outperformed. Weibo (WB) was on pace for its third straight gain, rising 4% to 44.94, but it still has its 50-day moving average to conquer just below 46. NetEase (NTES) is in the same situation as it tries to reclaim the 50-day line. Shares rose nearly 5%.RELATED:Amazon Wins Christmas, And Its 50-Day, As Macy's, Malls MauledJPMorgan, Goldman, Other Banks Fall As 10-Year Treasury Yields Drop

The key market indexes were narrowly mixed early Thursday after starting out underwater. The Nasdaq advanced, thanks to gains by big-cap techs including Apple (AAPL), Intel (INTC) and Microsoft (MSFT).The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average were down 0.1% and 0.2%, respectively, as the Nasdaq pulled ahead to a 0.2% gain. Volume was tracking slightly higher across the board vs. the same time Wednesday.Gold miners, chip and internet stocks led the upside in the stock market today, while department stores and other retailers underperformed. Department stores were the worst group, down more than 10%.Kohl's (KSS) gapped down and plunged 18%, diving below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages in rapid turnover. The department store operator cut its full-year earnings estimates late Wednesday to $2.92-$2.97 vs. its prior forecast of $3.12-$3.32.Macy's (M) gapped down and sank 13% to a five-month low in massive trade. Also after the close Wednesday, the department store chain cut its EPS outlook to $2.95-$3.10 from earlier guidance for $3.15-$3.40. It detailed plans to cut 10,000 jobs and shutter 68 stores.Both retailers reported a 2.1% drop in November-December same-store sales.Nvidia (NVDA) reversed from an early gain to fall 1.2% in heavy volume. Shares have been trying to recover from a recent slide after finding support near 100. Despite a decline stemming from a sharp 7% loss Dec. 28, the stock remains well above its 50-day line. But it's always better to buy stocks when they're rising, not falling. As noted in a recent Stock Market Today column, Nvidia's action signaled a climax run, a sell signal during bubblelike conditions in the market. In his widely anticipated keynote speech at CES Wednesday evening, CEO Jen-Hsun Huang introduced the Nvidia Drive PX2 AI car computer and announced partnerships as the company continues working on its self-driving car.In economic news, U.S. employers added 153,000 workers in December, according to ADP's national employment report, below expectations for 172,000. First-time jobless claims fell to 235,000 the week ended Dec. 31, below the prior week's 263,000 and views for 260,000 claims.RELATED:Kohl's, Macy's Slash Profit Guidance On Weak Holiday Sales: Blame Amazon?Nvidia CEO Details Bold Plans To Push Self-Driving CarsStocks Extend Gains After Fed Minutes; Can Nvidia Reverse Its Slide?

Restaurant stocks, airlines and department stores were under the analyst microscope Thursday morning, in particular: Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Southwest Airlines (LUV), United Airlines (UAL), Kohl's (KSS) and Macy's (M).Shares of both retailers are withering in early trade after logging poor holiday sales and cutting earnings forecasts late Wednesday.Robert W. Baird and Telsey Advisory Group slashed their ratings on Kohl's, with Baird downgrading the value department store chain to neutral from outperform and cutting its price target to 44 from 60. Telsey now has a market perform (from outperform) and 47 price target from 58.Macy's received price target cuts from RBC and Telsey to 35 (from 43) and 38 (from 42), respectively.Kohl's shares sank 19% to close at 42.01. Macy's tumbled 13.9% to 30.86.Wedbush's Nick Setyan upgraded the beleaguered fast-casual dining chain to neutral from underperform and boosted its price target to 400 from 370, citing "1) a lack of a postelection upward revaluation relative to peers; 2) a post-Q3 downward revision of 2017 Street expectations below our estimates; and 3) our belief that a recent shift toward a focus on margins vs. a recovery in sales renders lowered expectations realistic."Shares rose 2.6% to finish at 391.89 in the stock market today, moving back above the 50-day line.Meanwhile, Setyan downgraded BJ's Restaurants (BJRI) and Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD).Morgan Stanley downgraded United to equal-weight while upgrading Southwest to overweight.The bank's analyst action comes on the heel's of Cowen's slew of downgrades on Wednesday, taking the ratings ax to United, American Airlines (AAL), Alaska Air Group (ALK), JetBlue (JBLU) and budget carrier Spirit Airlines (SAVE).United shares ended down 2.9% Thursday while Southwest lost 1.6%.IBD'S TAKE: Cowen left Southwest's outperform rating well alone and called this airline a top pick.

U.S. stock indexes sagged midday Thursday, and moderately higher volume added some concern.The Nasdaq trimmed 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and the blue chip Dow Jones industrial average retreated 0.4% and 0.5%, respectively. The small-cap Russell 2000, which has been leading the market, dropped 1.3%. Volume was running modestly higher on both major exchanges in the stock market today.Blue chips were mostly down in the Dow. The two banks in the Dow — Goldman Sachs (GS) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) — fell more than 1.5% each. Payment processor Visa (V) scored the best gain, rising 1.2%. Visa is consolidating, but recently retook its 50-day moving average line. In the S&P 500, one of the day's best gainers was gold miner Newmont Mining (NEM). The big-cap stock gapped up almost 6% as it reclaimed its 200-day line. Newmont remains beaten down, 19% off its high even with the day's gap up. The biggest loser in the S&P 500 was retailer Kohl's (KSS), down 19%.The retail sector has done little in the so-called Trump rally. Just before the election, retail was No. 26 of 33 sectors. Going into Thursday's session, retail was No. 25.In the Nasdaq 100, retailer Urban Outfitters (URBN) was the worst performer, down 5% in heavy volume.In economic news, payroll firm ADP reported that businesses added 153,000 jobs in December, which was 11% fewer than the Street expected. First-time jobless claims rolled in at 235,000, which was almost 10% fewer than expected.Internationally, services gauges tilted toward the bullish side. China's services sector picked up to a 17-month high. The United Kingdom reported the fastest growth in the services sector since July 2015. Japan's services sector grew at the fastest pace in 11 months. Ireland's services index popped to a five-month high in December.But in India, the services gauge for December contracted for a second straight month. About a third of India's economy is informal, which makes official statistics and economic gauges imperfect.RELATED:Microsoft Price Target Raise; Surface Booms Vs. AppleIntel Promises Progress On Virtual Reality

Stocks opened narrowly mixed Thursday following a mixed bag of employment news.The Nasdaq rose less than 0.2% while the S&P 500 and Dow industrials lost less than 0.1%.The Nasdaq launched into Thursday's session up 1.7% in the holiday-shortened week. The S&P 500 holds a 1.4% gain and the Dow is ahead 0.9%. But the Nasdaq is carrying a heavy load of distribution days.Department stores were active, with Kohl's (KSS) down 18% and Macy's (M) taking a 13% hit as analyst downgrades followed the stores' weak holiday sales reported late Wednesday. Deutsche Bank downgraded Macy's to hold from buy, and slashed its price target to 34 from 47. Telsey Advisory Group cut Kohl's to market perform from outperform.Wal-Mart (WMT) dipped 1% on the Dow.Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) rumbled up 9% at the opening bell. The Connecticut-based biotech filed its third-quarter 10-Q report late Wednesday, marking the end of an internal accounting investigation. Alexion shares rose 31% from a June low and began basing in early November. There is a potential buy point at 134.16, but the stock has been contained by resistance at its 40-week moving average for the past year.Corporate research firm CEB (CEB) bolted 24% after information technology researcher Gartner (IT) said it would acquire the company in a $2.6 billion cash-stock deal. Gartner shares dropped 2% in early trading.Halozyme Therapeutics (HALO) spiked 12%. The San Diego-based biotech reported positive results in a Phase 2 clinical trial of its pancreatic cancer drug PEGPH20.U.S. employers trimmed payrolls by 33,627 workers in December, according to the monthly Job Cut Report from consultant Challenger, Gray & Christmas.  That was a 25% increase over November layoffs, which marked the lowest number of reductions during 2016. For the year, employers announced a total of 526,915 job cuts, 12% below 2015 levels and the annual 539,581 layoffs averaged since 2010.U.S. employers added a weaker-than-expected 153,000 workers in December, the National Employment Report from ADP estimated. Services sector employers added 163,000 positions, while goods-producing companies reduced their workforce by 16,000.First-time unemployment claims dropped to 235,000 in the week ended December 31, the Labor Department reported. That was down from 263,000 claims in the prior week and well below consensus views for 260,000 claims. the four-week average dropped to 256,750, its second straight decline after five weeks of increases.London-based researcher Markit offers up its December services Purchasing Managers' Index at 9:45 a.m. ET and at 10 a.m., look for the Institute for Supply Management's December Non-Manufacturing Index.Oil bumped up almost 1%, putting West Texas Intermediate near $54 a barrel. Gold climbed 1.1% to $1,177.60 an ounce. Platinum advanced almost 3%, trading up more than 7% so far this week. The dollar backed down sharply, while the 10-year Treasury yield slipped 3 basis points to 2.41%.In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng Index leapt 1.5% in a rally boosted by Wednesday's Fed minutes and led by energy and insurance companies. The Shanghai Composite added 0.2%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dipped 0.4%, easing after Wednesday's rally.European markets were mixed in afternoon trade, with the CAC 40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX down 0.1% apiece but sitting atop a four-week rally. London's FTSE 100 traded up 0.1%, briefly topping its prior high set in April 2010.RELATED:Disney, Netflix Climb Into Buy Zones: Investing Action Plan

Nike (NKE) topped fiscal Q3 forecasts after the close Thursday and signaled a recent sales slump in North America is ending, helping offset fears of a trade war sparked by President Trump's tariffs.Estimates: A 23.5% slide to 52 cents in per-share profit. Analysts see revenue rising 4.9% to $8.84 billion, according to Zacks Investment Research.Results: EPS of 68 cents, excluding tax-related charges, on revenue of $8.98 billion. North America revenue fell 6% to $3.57 billion with apparel flat and footwear down 8%. Europe, Middle East and Africa revenue jumped 19% to $2.3 billion. Greater China revenue surged 24% to $1.34 billion. Asia Pacific and Latin America revenue grew 13% to $1.27 billion."Nike's Consumer Direct Offense drove strong double-digit growth across our international geographies, led by Greater China," said Chairman and CEO Mark Parker in a statement. "As we close Q3, we now see a significant reversal of trend in North America, as momentum accelerates through the scaling of new innovation platforms and differentiated NIKE Consumer Experiences expand across the marketplace."Stock: Nike jumped 7.1% late. Shares closed down 2.9% at 64.42 on the stock market today, breaching their 50-day moving average as the Trump administration unveiled tariffs against China, which has been a top growth driver for Nike. Rival Under Armour (UAA) fell 1.4%. Major Nike retailer Foot Locker (FL) sank 4.3%.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseNorth America revenue has been in focus, as  sales have slumped while rival Adidas (ADDYY) has been gaining share on Nike's home turf and turned in double-digit growth during the holiday quarter.Adidas North America chief Mark King told Investor's Business Daily last week that its growth in the family channel — at stores such as Kohl's (KSS) and DSW (DSW) — and at Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS), where its training apparel is sold, are strong.But Nike's continued strong performance in China also underscores a vulnerability as Trump has directed relatively heavy economic fire toward China. Nike has echoed concerns from trade groups representing Walmart (WMT), Apple (AAPL), Best Buy (BBY) and other retailers warning that tariffs would raise prices for American consumers.Meanwhile, CEO Parker must grapple with other recent headlines. An informal survey about inappropriate behavior had been circulated by female Nike employees, reported the Wall Street Journal earlier in the week.The news followed the resignation of No. 2 executive and Nike Brand President Trevor Edwards and the exit of exec Jayme Martin, who was forced out amid complaints of misconduct. YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: Add These 6 Top-Rated Apparel Stocks To Your Watch List WardrobeYeezy Does It: Nordstrom Teams Up With Rare-Sneaker SpecialistTwo Nike Execs Step Down Amid Reports Of Misconduct Probe
