XThe Adidas rocket ship shows no signs of slowing: the latest semiannual teen survey from Piper Jaffray says that the resurgent athletic apparel brand has become the No. 1 new label worn by male teens, knocking out Nike (NKE), the Dow Jones industrial average component that has reigned in that category since fall of 2014.And overall, it the third most preferred fashion footwear brand among upper-income teens, "the highest it has been in 10 years," notes Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy in a separate note, raising her price target to 194 euro from 190. She also notched up full-year estimates on the Three Stripes.That doesn't mean that Nike is anywhere near losing its market share dominance, however. Among all upper-income and average income teens, the Swoosh remains the top athletic clothing brand with 69% of the vote in each segment. Adidas, while still the fastest growing brand in Piper Jaffray's poll, sits in the No. 2 spot with less than 10% of the vote.And in athletic footwear among all teens, Nike holds on tight to its top position with 80% share of the survey."While (Nike) remains the No. 1 footwear brand, we are seeing strong signs that adidas is gaining back share among males & hitting an all-time high with females," said Murphy.Meanwhile, Under Armour (UAA) topped one of the charts in a less stellar way, becoming the No. 1 brand that's no longer being worn by upper-income teenage boys.Under Armour recently was added to midmarket department story Kohl's (KSS), which some analysts wondering if that would undermine the brand. Nike has been at Kohl's and other big-box retailers for years.IBD'S TAKE: Under Armour's first month at Kohl's was considered underwhelming, amid an "intensifying" price war between the Baltimore-based brand and Nike.Dow's Nike fell 0.4% to 54.90 in afternoon trade in the stock market today. Under Armour sank 0.65%, stuck in a long downtrend. Adidas' U.S. shares retreated 0.3%.For all three brands, however, the survey confirms a reassuring trend: activewear is still very in."We have seen the drumbeat for athletic beat louder with every iteration of our Teen Survey," wrote Murphy. "Simply stated, teens — both male & female — are opting for athletic/casual brands as their top apparel & footwear choices."RELATED:Dow Component Nike Earns A Downgrade, Thanks To Under Armour, AdidasWalt Disney Is In Buy Range, And You Can Thank TeensMore Teens Than Ever Expect Next Phone To Be An iPhone: Piper JaffrayLululemon Athletica Plunges Late On Earnings Miss, 'Slow Start' In 2017Finish Line's Dismal Earnings, Guidance Follow Nike's Retail Warning

XThe main indexes remained higher in afternoon trading Thursday, as small caps and retail stocks led a soft bounce in the market.Despite a bearish reversal Wednesday, the S&P 500 was up 0.4% and finding support near the 50-day moving average. That suggests the index can stay on track with its uptrend, although some institutional selling over the past several weeks poses a threat.The Dow Jones industrial average, also up 0.4%, is tracing a similar chart. Most of its 30 components were higher, with Home Depot's (HD) 0.6% rise adding to the gains in retail. Wal-Mart (WMT), however, was flat.The Nasdaq composite rose 0.3%. But it was small caps that shined brighter, as the Russell 2000 climbed 0.5%. The index, though, remains below the 50-day moving average. Volume was lower across the board.Retail stocks led the market today. Apparel firms, discounters, department stores and other retail groups — all of them in the lagging industry rankings — were up 2% to 4.5%. Kohl's (KSS) jumped 6.5%, but like other department-store stocks it remains deep in a correction.Fortune Brands Home & Security (FBHS) broke out of a cup-with-handle base, leaping past the 61.77 buy point in about one-third more volume than usual. The company's home brands include Master Lock, Moen faucets and several cabinet lines.Sociedad Quimica y Minera (SQM) broke out of a base-on-base pattern, surging past a 34.94 buy point in nearly double its usual volume. The Chilean provider of fertilizers and lithium and other chemicals is turning itself around, going from a few quarters of declining EPS to gains of 320% and 82% the past two quarters.Applied Optoelectronics (AAOI) found support after a sharp pullback to the 10-week moving average. Volume was tracking at three times the average.The IBD 50 was indicated 0.6% higher, and some of its semiconductor stocks behaved favorably.Cavium (CAVM), one of the many new technology components on the screen, rose 0.5% as the stock climbs from support at the 50-day moving average. Volume was tracking well below usual levels, so the stock may need more of a push before it can be considered in a new buy area. It would be a secondary entry for the chip stock, which has glided well from a flat base breakout Dec. 6.Monolithic Power Systems (MPWR) made a bullish reversal after touching its 50-day line. But the stock remains below the most recent buy point at 91.86.RELATED:Are Retail Stocks Doomed? Shorting Potential Abounds, But Hope Remains

X Shares of Under Armour (UAA) dropped Monday amid a downgrade to underperform from FBR Capital and lukewarm findings from Piper Jaffray on the athletic apparel brand's performance at Kohl's (KSS) so far.FBR analyst Susan Anderson cut her rating on Under Armour and pulled her price target to 14 from 20. Among other factors, she cited the brand's declining popularity in an FBR poll, dearth of footwear innovation, plus an "intensifying" price war between Nike (NKE) and Under Armour following the latter's debut at Kohl's a month ago.At direct-to-consumer channels, Nike outlets have been more promotional, said Anderson, and Under Armour has been discounting "significantly" year over year. At the wholesale level, athletic goods outlets such as Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) and department stores such as Macy's (M) have "ramped up promos, we believe in response to intensified promos now at Kohl's, particularly in men's/kids'," she wrote.Piper Jaffray noted separately that both brands have been promotional at Kohl's, though "Nike still outsells Under Armour," despite consumer interest in Under Armour's arrival at the midtier department store. Analyst Erinn Murphy also pointed to Under Armour's sluggishness at Kohl's in the key women's segment, and concern that the brand's debut isn't bringing in incremental customers."We worry that Kohl's $3.5 billion Athletic & Wellness category cannot sustain (double-digit) growth in 2017 and the addition of UAA will likely have cannibalistic effects on peer athletic brands," she said. "Our concerns about UAA's ability to drive sales as KSS were escalated further when DSW (DSW) announced it will be carrying UAA in time for back-to-school 2017."Meanwhile, a Barron's report that the stock could ascend by 30% in a year, reportedly on its prospects at Kohl's and room to run abroad.Under Armour shares initially rose in the stock market today, reversed as low as 19.20 before closing at 19.63, off 0.8%.Barron's highlighted Under Armour's investments in collegiate sponsorships and its prominence in the NCAA Final Four after spending $71 million across a decade to become the outfitter of the South Carolina Gamecocks.South Carolina brought home the women's national championship title on Sunday after beating Mississippi State. In the men's division, the Gamecocks lost 73-77 to the Gonzaga Bulldogs on Saturday.North Carolina and Gonzaga will face off in the championship game Monday night. Both are sponsored by Nike.Nike shares fell 0.3%. Adidas (ADDYY) slid 1.1%. Kohl's retreated 1.7%.

XFutures for the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq 100 signaled modest gains early Monday.Dow component Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) is back in buying range as the world's largest retailer appears to be a rare brick-and-mortar operator holding its ground against e-commerce giant Amazon.com (AMZN). Meanwhile, Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) faces a new issue that could tarnish its brand.The Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq composite suffered slim losses last week. The Dow industrials and S&P 500 index are once again trading right at their 50-day moving averages.Dow Jones industrial average futures rose about 0.2% vs. fair value. So did S&P 500 index and Nasdaq 100 futures. U.S. crude oil futures extended gains above $52 a barrel, rising 0.5% overnight after last week's 3.2% gain amid America's military strike in Syria.Wal-Mart rose 2.1% to 72.90 in Friday stock market trading, rising to its best level since last September. The Dow industrials stock also retook a 72.58 buy point briefly cleared in late February. That comes as many major retailers, including Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS) and Target (TGT), have been falling near multiyear lows.IBD'S TAKE: The retail industry is facing an existential crisis, and not in the depths of the recession. Amid brutal competition and a massive shift online, death stalks retail, but hope lives on.Wal-Mart has revitalized its e-commerce efforts, helped by a series of acquisitions, including Jet.com last year. Wal-Mart put Jet.com founder Marc Lore in charge of all its online efforts.Fourth-quarter online sales surged 29%. But Wal-Mart is doing more than holding its own. It's actually forced Amazon to adapt.In late January, Wal-Mart ended its ShippingPass subscription program, its attempt to imitate Amazon Prime. Instead, Wal-Mart announced that it would offer free two-day shipping for online orders of at least $35. Amazon soon cut its non-Prime free shipping to $35, though its deliveries will take five to eight days.Separately, Alphabet's Google denied Labor Department claims of widespread pay disparity between men and women. "Every year, we do a comprehensive and robust analysis of pay across genders and we have found no gender pay gap," Google said in an emailed statement Sunday.A Labor Department official reportedly testified Friday that the government found women being paid less "pretty much across the entire workforce."Alphabet has been trying to deal with an uproar from advertisers for their Google YouTube ads being placed against racist or other objectionable videos. Many top advertisers have suspended YouTube spending in recent weeks.Alphabet fell fractionally on Friday to 842.10, closing below its 50-day line for a second straight session.Asian MarketsAsian markets were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei up 0.6% intraday, Hong Kong's Hang Seng flat and China's Shanghai composite off 0.2%.RELATED:Wal-Mart Gives Strong Revenue Guidance As Q4 Online Sales Soar 29%These 3 Banking Giants Kick Off Earnings Season: Investing Action PlanThese 4 Dow Stocks, 3 Big-Name Techs Should Be On Your Trading Radar

Sears Holdings (SHLD) plunged Wednesday after disclosing late Tuesday said past results "indicate substantial doubt exists" over the retailer's ability to stay alive, while Bebe (BEBE) reportedly mulls shutting all of its stores and Payless is expected to file for bankruptcy protection.The convulsions are the latest additions to the dirge coming from the sector as Amazon (AMZN) drains the life from brick-and-mortar retailers."Our historical operating results indicate substantial doubt exists related to the Company's ability to continue as a going concern," said the operator of Sears and Kmart stores in its annual report.The warning, first reported earlier by the Street, came as Macy's (M) on Tuesday caved through January support levels to a five-year low. J.C. Penney (JCP), Kohl's (KSS) and other department stores broke through various support areas.Sears shares sank 12.3% to 7.98 on the stock market today, but closing off intraday lows to finish above the 50-day line. The stock is still off 2017 lows set during a liquidity scare.Meanwhile, Bebe, which has about 170 boutique and outlet women's apparel stores, is trying to avoid a bankruptcy filing by shutting its stores and becoming an online brand, but the women's apparel chain may be forced to file for Chapter 11 if enough landlords don't negotiate, sources told Bloomberg. Bebe, which plunged 44.5% on Tuesday, rose 8.1% on Wednesday.Discount shoe retailer Payless may file for bankruptcy protection as soon as next week, and could close 400-500 stores, according to a separate Bloomberg report.Macy's fell 0.2%, J.C. Penney lost 0.7% while Kohl's rose 0.2%, all closing off intraday lows.RELATED:Macy's Breaks Support As Amazon, Wal-Mart Squeeze Retailers

Stocks lost ground Wednesday, and the Nasdaq was once again rebuffed at its 50-day line. The action, though, left a question lingering: What's ahead for this uptrend?While the action around the Nasdaq's 50-day line might seal the uptrend's fate to the satisfaction of either the bulls or the bears, what will boost or weigh on the Nasdaq? Earnings season is well underway but could still play a key role. On Thursday, some key quarterly reports will be released.Before the open, watch for these two reports:-- Specialty department store Kohl's (KSS) is expected to report a 41% drop in earnings to 37 cents a share vs. the year-ago quarter. Revenue growth is expected to be flat. The stock plunged 6% Wednesday, caught up in a sell-off among retail stocks.-- Consumer staples provider Prestige Brands (PBH) will report a 4% earnings gain to 49 cents a share, if analysts are correct. Revenue is pegged at under 5%. The stock fell 1% Wednesday.After the close Thursday, watch for these three reports:-- Restaurant chain Shake Shack (SHAK) is seen delivering a 25% pop in earnings to 5 cents a share. The revenue target is about 38%. The January 2015 initial public offering slid 4.5% Wednesday.-- Brazil-based integrated oil company Petrobras (PBR) is expected to post an 84% plunge in earnings to 4 cents a share. Analysts expect revenue to fall 16.5%. Brazil is struggling with a bad economy and a political impeachment issue.-- Chip designer Nvidia (NVDA) is pegged for a 3% earnings drop to 32 cents a share. Revenue growth is expected to roll in at almost 10%. The stock edged up 0.3% Wednesday.News apart from the earnings season also can have an impact.On Thursday, the Labor Department will release first-time jobless claims. When it rains, grab an umbrella. The managers of $799 million Oppenheimer Discovery Mid Cap Growth Fund (OEGAX) are applying that adage about finding shelter in a storm to their mutual fund.Amid a blah macroeconomic environment, they've been betting that the few companies capable of generating superior growth will be increasingly attractive to investors. Those are the stocks they are aiming for, according to their March 31 commentary.Hasbro (HAS), the world's second-largest publicly traded toy company, was a key contributor to fund performance in the first quarter. It was helped by holiday-season sales of toys based on the big success of "Star Wars: The Force Awakens," a film that was released in December.Q4 sales rose 13% as earnings per share climbed 14%. Hasbro has quickened its pace. Q1 revenue rose 16%, driving an 81% EPS surge. EPS have grown three quarters in a row.Shares are up 29% so far this year, going into Friday.The stock has a 2.4% dividend yield. And it as a 99 Composite Rating from IBD.The stock got powerful free advertising in recent days. Texas mom Candace Payne donned a mask depicting "Star Wars" character Chewbacca that emitted the Wookiee’s trademark growl every time Payne opened her mouth. A video of Payne laughing hysterically as the mask growled -- dubbed "Happy Chewbacca" -- was posted on Facebook (FB), drawing over 140 million views as of Tuesday.As IBD reported, Piper Jaffray said the video could drive sales of 1 million units or more of the $30 mask, generating 2 to 3 cents of near-term EPS for Hasbro.Kohl's (KSS) posted a video of Payne and her family, further promoting Hasbro products.Then Payne appeared on CBS’ (CBS) "The Late Late Show," recreating her viral video hit, with host James Corden and "Star Wars" director J.J. Abrams also wearing the Hasbro-made masks.The highest Comp Rating is 99. The Comp Rating combines IBD’s five performance ratings, including EPS and Relative Strength ratings. Stocks poised to move higher often have a high Comp Rating.Seven of the fund's top 10 holdings as of March 31 had Comp Ratings of 80 or higher. So did eight of the fund's 10 top new buys.Trading around 256, top-10 holding Acuity Brands (AYI) is extended from an earlier entry at 225.28 and from an alternate entry at 242, as IBD's markets team points out. The stock has a 98 Comp Rating and a dividend yield of 0.2%.

It's now working on a new flat base with a 260.93 buy point. Its Accumulation/Distribution is neutral at C, but the rating is offset by a strong up/down volume ratio.The supplier of lighting products is seeing strong demand. On April 6, Acuity reported earnings per share in the February-ended fiscal second quarter of $1.80 a share, up 53% and nicely above analysts' consensus estimate of $1.51. Sales rose 26% to $777.8 million. Analysts were modeling $752.3 million.Ulta Salon (ULTA), another top holding, is up 14% so far this year.

Ulta has a 99 Comp Rating.In after-hours trading, Ulta jumped 7% after the big-box cosmetics retailer reported that fiscal Q1 profit rose 39% to $1.45 a share on a 24% increase in sales to $1.07 billion. Wall Street was looking for $1.29 in per-share profit on $1.03 billion in revenue. EPS grew 22%, 22% and 27% in the previous three quarters.Ulta, which rose 1% to a new high during the regular session, has climbed out of buy range following a March breakout past a 188.58 buy point.Previously, the beauty segment has been lauded as Amazon (AMZN)-proof by analysts who cite the strength of Ulta and Sephora’s loyalty programs and the fact that customers like to sample cosmetics in-person.Intuitive Surgical (ISRG), a top new buy, is suturing up gains within the medical sector. The company is debt free.After EPS shrank in all four quarters of 2014 and grew just 1% in Q1 2015, it has grown at a double-digit pace in four frames since then. Revenue grew 7%, 12% and 12% the past three stanzas.Intuitive Surgical was not hurt by a May 12 U.S. District Court ruling that, if upheld, would bar government payments of billions of dollars to insurance companies participating in ObamaCare, enabling the insurers to reduce customers' out-of-pocket costs, such as deductibles for low-income people.Shares of many insurance-oriented health care stocks went down after the decision.Ronald Zibelli Jr. took the fund's helm on June 5, 2007. Justin Livengood has been on the job with him since early 2014. The fund is an IBD Best Mutual Funds 2016 Awards winner among midcaps for outperforming the S&P 500 over the one-, three-, five- and 10-year periods ended Dec. 31.The fund's 7.36% average annual gain over the decade going into Thursday ranks in the top 35% of its midcap growth rivals tracked by Morningstar Inc. Its peers averaged 6.81% and the S&P 500 averaged 7.36%.Over the past three years the fund outperformed 86% of its peers. So far this year, its 0.30% loss tops 44% of its direct competitors.

Troubled department store chain JCPenney (JCP) reportedly has slashed employee hours and frozen overtime to avoid missing its quarterly targets, according to the New York Post late Thursday.Those and other temporary measures -- such as prohibiting markdowns -- were taken as the company noted an "expense challenge" in April and beseeched stores to "do their fair share by closely monitoring all expenses," according to a memo acquired by the media outlet.Shares closed down 7.5% on the stock market today, gapping down past their 200-day line Friday.A severe cut in full-time and part-time employee hours -- from 25 weekly hours to 10 or 15 -- reportedly helped the company save $8,000 per store over two weeks. JCPenney has over 1,000 store locations in the U.S. and Puerto Rico.The Post, citing a source, said workers were stunned by the short notice of the cuts.JCPenney reports first-quarter earnings the morning of Friday, May 13.Department store retailers have been having a bad week. Shares of IBD's Retail-Department Stores industry group -- which includes Nordstrom (JWN), Macy's (M), JCPenney and others -- lost 5.7% vs. last Friday. Macy's, Nordstrom and Kohl's (KSS) also report quarterly earnings next week.

XAmazon.com (AMZN) is hiring 30,000 part-time workers, mostly for fulfillment centers and customer service positions, in the next year.Roughly 5,000 will be work-from-home customer service positions, Amazon said in an announcement.The e-commerce giant employs more than 180,000 people, as well as some 40,000 part-time employees across the U.S. In January, Amazon announced plans to add 100,000 full-time jobs by mid-2018."There are lots of people who want or need a flexible job — whether they're a military spouse, a college student, or a parent — and we're happy to empower these talented people no matter where they happen to live," said Tom Weiland, Amazon VP for worldwide customer service, in a release. "We're finding that roles with Virtual Customer Service are particularly attractive to military spouses who want to continue working and parenting, even if their spouse is deployed or the family is relocated, as often happens with military families."Amazon stock slipped 1.2% to 898.28 in the stock market today, edging down from an all-time high set on Wednesday.IBD'S TAKE: Amazon — as well as Apple and Tesla — are on IBD's Leaderboard, which follows top stocks from their work on forming bases, through their breakouts, to their post-breakout action, up to the point where they start topping.But, Amazon's relentless online competition has forced department stores and other retailers to close stores.Department stores such as Macy's (M), J.C. Penney (JCP) and Kohl's (KSS) sold off in March, as investors worried over Amazon's clout as shoppers increasingly shift to e-commerce sites.IBD's Retail-Department Store group continues to rank dead last out of the 197 industries that IBD tracks.RELATED:Department Stores Continue To Dive As Investors Doubt Viability Vs. Amazon

Department stores such as Macy's (M), J.C. Penney (JCP) and Kohl's (KSS) sold off Monday on little news, as investors continue to lower their prospects for traditional retailers as shoppers increasingly shift to Amazon.com (AMZN) and other e-commerce sites.Macy's fell 3.8% to 29.37 on the stock market today, trading at its lowest levels since early February, when takeover buzz began.Kohl's sank 4.8% to 38.56, setting a seven-month low intraday.J.C. Penney retreated 2.3% to 5.85, hitting a five-year low. Regional department store operator Dillard's tumbled 4.5% to 49.79, also hitting its worst levels since early 2012.IBD's Retail-Department Store group, rated dead last out of the 197 industries that IBD tracks, was the biggest losers in Monday's session. Macy's and Kohl's were among the very worst performers on the S&P 500 index Monday.Department stores are working hard to try to be viable, emphasizing their online presence. But Amazon is grabbing a huge share of online sales growth and boasts bigger shipping discounts than even major retailers. Brick-and-mortar chains hope to better-leverage physical stores for online pickups and returns. But at the same time they are slashing their store count. That lowers costs, but calls into question the very omnichannel model they are trying to use to battle Amazon.IBD'S TAKE: Despite their brick-and-mortar woes, traditional retailers are seeing big online sales gains, but from very low levels.Target (TGT) fell intraday to a five-year low, though the retailer closed up 8 cents to 54.37. Target has been lumped in with department stores, especially after its weak Q4 earnings report and guidance.Amazon, for its part, rose 0.55% to 856.99. Amazon is still in buy range from an 821.75 entry and is setting up in a four-weeks-tight pattern with an 860.76 buy point.As for other retailers, Wal-Mart (WMT) isn't doing as badly as some of its rivals. Wal-Mart saw sharp online sales growth over the holidays, with U.S. same-store sales rising. Wal-Mart is re-emphasizing lower prices, a push that's squeezing everyone from Macy's to Target to grocers such as Kroger (KR).Wal-Mart shares closed up 0.1% to 59.98 Monday. But Wal-Mart stock is below its 200-day line and its relative strength line shows the retail giant is an S&P 500 laggard.Off-price retailers such as TJX (TJX) and Burlington Stores (BURL) are near highs, but they too retreated Monday, down 1.3% and 2%, respectively.RELATED:Macy's, Costco, Kohl's And Other Retailers Are Getting SlammedRetailers Face 2017 'Reckoning,' More 'Sad Malls' As Amazon Keeps BoomingTarget Dives To 2014 Levels: 'We're Slow And Have Too Much Inventory'J.C. Penney To Close 130-140 Stores After Mixed Q4, Comp Sales Drop

Shares of Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS), Nordstrom (JWN), J.C. Penney (JCP), Costco Wholesale (COST) and other retailers are getting slammed Monday, but it's not yet clear what exactly is weighing on the sector.Macy's closed down 3.4% at 30.69 on the stock market today after losing 4.4% on Friday. Kohl's also lost 3.4%, Nordstrom 1.8%, J.C. Penney 4.8%. IBD's Retail-Department store group fell 3.3% Monday, one of the very worst performers out of 197 industries that IBD tracks.IBD'S TAKE: Macy's has been added to IBD's Leaderboard, which provides annotated chart analysis of actionable stocks. Leaderboard typically focuses on growth stocks at or near buy points, but Macy's is among a new crop of possible short sales.February store sales sank 17%, said Business Insider on Monday, citing Bloomberg and First Data. That data appeared to be public last week, per a tweet from Bloomberg reporter Jodi Xu Klein:U.S. department store Feb sales downs 17%, tax refunds may help, says Bloomberg Intelligence #retailers— Jodi Xu Klein (@jodixu) March 3, 2017Meanwhile, the New York Post reported late Friday that Macy's bidder Hudson's Bay isn't pleased with the "high price" being asked for the nation's largest department store chain. Hudson's Bay also hasn't lined up financing yet for a Macy's bid, Reuters reported on Friday.And NPD Group said Monday that apparel sales grew 3% in 2016 to reach $218.7 billion, but were struggling to rise beyond that."The industry had positive overall performance with growth in most categories, but it has struggled to exceed 3% sales growth since 2013, as significant gains in select consumer and retail segments were offset by declines in others," said NPD.Costco and Target (TGT) are also swept up in Monday's downward action. Costco fell 2.1%, undercutting its 50-day line intraday. Costco gapped down 4.4% on Friday following its report of weaker-than-expected earnings and sales.Target, which crashed 14% last week on its own weak results and guidance, lost 2.2%. But Wal-Mart (WMT) dipped just 0.2%.Retail Metrics head Ken Perkins says there's "no specific reason" he's aware of for the broad sector decline, though "you can probably take your pick."Among those issues he cited: delayed tax refunds, broader Q4 earnings weakness — down 2.1% year-over-year, he said — concern over the border adjustment tax, high levels of distressed debt in retail, and of course, Amazon (AMZN).Perkins also noted that retail earnings pre-announcements "are running 5-1 negative-to-positive so far this earnings season."RELATED:Target Dives To 2014 Levels: 'We're Slow And Have Too Much Inventory'Costco To Raise Membership Fees After Fiscal Q2 Earnings, Sales MissJ.C. Penney To Close 130-140 Stores After Mixed Q4, Comp Sales DropAs 'Amazon Effect' Barrels On, Here's How Big Box Retailers Are Faring OnlineMacy's Eyes 'Entertainment Options' After Profit, Sales Fall For 8th Quarter

Macy's (M) stock plunged to its lowest level since 2011 on Tuesday, reflecting a broader market sell-off and an ongoing plunge for department stores and many other brick-and-mortar retailers as they deal with an ever-larger Amazon.com (AMZN) and a reinvigorated Wal-Mart (WMT).The department store chain's stock was down 3.2% to 28.42 in the stock market today, tumbling through its January support levels. Shares closed off their session lows but are nearing their next level of support — 22.66 — the low point of a cup base formed in the summer and fall during that year.J.C. Penney (JCP) fell 3.8% to a fresh 3-year low, Dillards (DDS) 3.6% to a five-year low. Nordstrom (JWN) lost 1.9% and Kohl's (KSS) 2.4%, both hitting their lowest levels since last August. IBD's Retail-Department Store group, ranked dead last out of 197 industry groups, is one of Tuesday's big losers after being Monday's worst performer.The SPDR S&P Retail ETF (XRT) stabbed through the bottom of a flat base, falling 2%.IBD'S TAKE: After a wave of grim holiday-quarter reports, retailers have been rushing to invest more in e-commerce. The existential crisis among brick-and-mortar retailers has grown more acute in recent months.Grim holiday-quarter results, bankruptcy filings and planned store-closures have piled up as Amazon sucks the life from malls and a younger generation of shoppers spends its money on experiences rather than things. Home-improvement and off-price retail, which are seen as more immune to e-commerce, are among the few bright spots. Meanwhile, Wal-Mart, a member of the Dow Jones industrial average, has begun a new price war — pinching discounters, department stores and grocery stores. Wal-Mart had strong online sales, and has continued an e-commerce buying spree and expansion.Amazon fell 1.6% after hitting an all-time high in morning action. Wal-Mart edged down just 0.1%.Department stores are working to develop their own small-but-fast-growing e-commerce sales, but closing physical stores also limits the omnichannel pickup and return options.RELATED:Department Stores Continue To Dive As Investors Doubt Viability Vs. AmazonTrump Seeks Retail Growth As CEOs Try To Block Border TaxBurlington Rebrands Itself To Show It's More Than Just Coats

Federal withheld income and employment taxes, the broadest and most reliable gauge of the state of the job market, grew 4.5% from a year ago in the four weeks through May 20, an IBD analysis of daily Treasury statements finds.That's the fastest pace in more than six months, providing confirmation that the economy is gaining steam after two weak quarters.The tax data, which don't rely on limited sample sizes and seasonal adjustments, had been signaling weaker wage gains than the monthly employment reports, which do require such guesswork. That may help explain how the economy slowed so much over the past two quarters even as job growth remained solid.The upturn in tax-receipt growth since mid-April could be a precursor to another strong employment report, including a further rise in wage growth that pushes the Federal Reserve closer to a June rate hike.After bottoming out at about 2% year-over-year growth in February, income and employment taxes have staged a recovery, propelled by announced pay hikes at Wal-Mart (WMT), Target (TGT) and Costco (COST).A number of companies reporting earnings over the past month also have highlighted wage pressures."We're facing an unprecedented environment for retaining and hiring talent," Panera Bread (PNRA) President Drew Madsen said on the restaurant chain's first-quarter earnings call.The company noted a 5% rise in retail hourly wage inflation during the quarter, as well as an increase in bonuses for bakery cafe managers.Wendy's (WEN) said it's seeing wage inflation of 5% to 6%, driven both by minimum-wage hikes and the need to offer a competitive wage "to access good labor."Kohl's (KSS) CEO Kevin Mansell said the retailer also is "experiencing significant wage pressure."The 4.5% rate of growth in withheld income and employment taxes is roughly consistent with annual payroll gains of 2% and wage gains of 2.5%. That's still pretty modest compared to gains upward of 5% in the first half of 2015 and 7% before the recession. But Fed policymakers aren't prepared to wait for more normal wage growth to resume normalizing interest rates.The U.S. is "basically at full employment or very near it," San Francisco Fed President John Williams said Monday.

Shares of Children's Place (PLCE) gapped up in the stock market today, a rare bright spot for the retail space after the children's apparel retailer beat first-quarter estimates and boosted its profit forecasts.Children's Place reported a 59% surge in first-quarter earnings per share to $1.32, well above estimates for $1.04 and the best gain going back at least past five years. Net sales also topped views, rising 3.6% to $419.4 million, compared with expectations for $417.59 million. Comps rose 5.1%.The clothier expects full-year earnings per share of $4.17-$4.27, up from an earlier outlook $4.00-$4.10. The more upbeat forecast comes "despite the challenging environment and continued weakness in store traffic," Children's Place said.The full-year outlook includes a 12-cent hit from adverse foreign exchange, "assumes a low single digit comp sales increase, expansion of gross margin and disciplined expense control.”Still, for the second quarter, the company sees a net loss of 22-30 cents per share, worse than analysts' consensus for 22 cents per share.Children's Place stock rose 4.1% to 71.05 Tuesday after climbing as high as 74.40 in the morning.The stock jumped in March after Children's Place reported fourth-quarter results, but shares began to crumble last month and were driven down further last week amid grim news and forecasts from retailers like Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS), Gap (GPS) and Nordstrom (JWN).Macy's stock fell 1.1%, Kohl's 2.7% and Nordstrom 2.3%. Gap, which reports full first-quarter results on Thursday, sank 1.2%. E-commerce sites like Amazon (AMZN), competitive promotions and a mild winter in some areas have hurt retailers' results, although some analysts believe that value chains have an advantage over their upscale rivals."We believe that the current trend to value over brand is here to stay," Morningstar analyst Bridget Weishaar said in a note about discount apparel chain operator TJX Cos. (TJX) last week.TJX shares rose 0.5% Tuesday after the off-price retailer reported first-quarter results that beat estimates and raised full-year EPS guidance.Five Below (FIVE), a teen-centric discounter, fell fractionally.

TJX (TJX) and Ross Stores (ROST) are on tap to report this week, so here's a brief look at what investors can expect from the off-pricers in the wake of last week's retail beatdown.Department stores collectively crumbled on earnings results last week, with Nordstrom (JWN) shares descending a whopping 18.5% by Friday's close, while Macy's (M) lost 17.1%, and Kohl's (KSS) sank 13.6%.But analysts generally agree that off-price retailers are the best positioned in a broader sector plagued by pure plays like Amazon (AMZN), weak apparel trends, and younger shoppers that are shying away from the mall.TJX profit is expected to climb 3% to 71 cents a share on 6% revenue growth to $7.3 billion.  The T.J. Maxx, Marshalls and HomeGoods parent reports Tuesday before the open.Meanwhile, Ross Stores earnings and revenue are both expected to rise 6%, posting 73 cents a share profit on sales of $3.1 billion. The company discloses results late Thursday.TJX shares are building a flat base above their 200-day line, though the stock is currently trading below the key 50-day level. Ross shares look similar, also working on a flat base above their 200-day line but below their 50-day.Both stocks held steadier than their retail counterparts last week, only losing around 5% by Friday's close. On Monday, Ross closed up 2.6%, and TJX added 3.45% on the stock market.RELATED:Retailers Lick Wounds, As JCPenney Results Cap Week From HellRetail Sales Spike 1.3%, Best Gain In A Year, Easing Consumer Fears.

Home Depot (HD) crushed first-quarter estimates and raised its full-year guidance, as customers of the home improvement retail giant paid an extra 2.4% per visit, or an average $60.03 during the period, the company said Tuesday.But its shares fell early on the stock market today after Chief Financial Officer Carol Tome told analysts on the earnings call that sales at stores open at least a year fell from 10.2% in February to 6.7% in March and then to 4.3% in April. Home Depot stock stayed down and ended the trading day off 2.5% to 132."It does dovetail with a bit of a spending slowdown we saw at a number of retailers that pointed to April being a slower month," Retail Metrics President Ken Perkins told IBD.Home Depot is more insulated from the Amazon.com (AMZN) effect than other retailers, such as apparel chains, Perkins said. So its slowing same-store sales at outlets open more than a year aren't as much of a red flag as they are for top chains like Macy's (M), Nordstrom (JWN), Kohl's (KSS) and Gap (GPS). Those four retailers reported dismal results last week, sparking a sell-off in the sector.Perkins likes prospects for Home Depot and rival Lowe's this year."We visited a number of retailers including Home Depot throughout the spring and they and Lowe's (LOW) were the busiest stores we visited," Perkins said.Home Depot's adjusted first-quarter earnings of $1.44 a share were up 24.1% year over year, according to figures provided by Thomson Reuters. Revenue grew 9% to $22.76 billion amid continued strong housing market growth, favorable spring weather and sustained consumer spending.Wall Street expected $1.36 earnings per share and $22.39 billion in revenue for the fiscal quarter ended May 1.Home Depot Chief Executive Craig Menear said in a press release that it was a "stronger-than-expected start to the year" and noted it came in "a quarter marked by week-to-week demand spikes caused by weather variability."Home Depot raised its 2016 earnings view to $6.27 a share, a penny above analysts' forecasts. It also lifted its sales projection for the year to 6.3% growth to about $94.097 billion, topping estimates of $94.082 billion. The company also projects same-store sales -- sales at outlets open more than a year -- will be up about 4.9% for the year, though that would be below first-quarter same-store sales growth of 6.5%.Shares initially fell more than 2% in morning trading, falling through their 50-day moving average. They recovered somewhat before tumbling even further by the close.After consolidating for nearly three months, the company's stock climbed above a 135.57 buy point on April 18 and rose to a fresh all-time high at 137.82 on May 10 before consolidating again.Jared Wiesel, partner at corporate consulting firm Revenue Analytics noted that the company is focusing on engaging millenials. For example, Home Depot is employing omni-media marketing that employs everything from print to digital."Their online sales were up 21.5% for the quarter, which is excellent," Weisel said.Wiesel said that some investors may be concerned that what would normally be early summer sales were pulled into the first quarter because of favorable weather, which could hurt second-quarter results."There could be an expectation that this quarter was so strong at the expense of future quarters," Wiesel said.Home Depot’s earnings came on the heels of the Commerce Department's announcement on Monday that U.S. housing starts climbed a strong 6.6% to a seasonally adjusted annual pace of 1.17 million units, topping estimates of 1.13 million.The government also revised March starts up a bit to a 1.10 million-unit rate from 1.09. The housing starts data and strong April retail sales indicate that economic growth is picking up momentum after getting off to a sluggish start in 2016."Our view of the macro environment remains consistent. We believe housing data indicates continued tailwinds for our business," CEO Menear told analysts on an earnings call early Tuesday.CFO Tome added: "We estimate weather driven demand positively impacted U.S. sales growth by approximately $250 million."Lowe's (LOW) is set to announce first-quarter financial results early Wednesday. Analysts predict earnings per share will rise 21% to 85 cents and revenue should jump 5.1% to $14.87 billion. Shares lost 1.2% at the close.

E-commerce leader Amazon (AMZN) announced a slew of new products and services at its annual cloud computing conference this week and also received its highest price target hike ever.X D.A. Davidson analyst Tom Forte on Thursday raised his price target on Amazon to 1,500 from 1,300, a new Wall Street high target and a 29% premium from where the stock currently trades.Forte focused on Amazon's growing physical footprint through its acquisition of Whole Foods, its partnership with Kohl's (KSS) and 10 bookstores."We believe Amazon's increased physical footprint (including 465 Whole Foods locations, around 10 bookstores, and its strategic partnership with Kohl's) is THE story of its 2017 holiday sales and an indication of things to come as Amazon increasingly leverages physical stores to increase its revenue growth and wallet share," Forte wrote in a note to clients.Also raising his price target on Amazon on Thursday was MKM Partners analyst Rob Sanderson, to 1,350 from 1,275. He called Amazon the "best long-term growth story available" for investors looking at large-cap stocks.Amazon shares climbed 1.3% to close at 1,176.75 on the stock market today.The price-target hikes come as Amazon is presenting its new products and services to 43,000 attendees at its Amazon Web Services annual "re:Invent" conference in Las Vegas this week. Amazon on Wednesday announced five new machine learning services, in addition to a video camera for developers. Collectively, Amazon is delivering tools for developers to help them build, deploy and manage their own machine learning systems.Machine learning is an application of artificial intelligence that provides systems the ability to learn and improve from experience without being explicitly programmed. Amazon also announced an expansion of database services on AWS."The 2017 narrative at re:Invent made it clear to us that AWS is focusing new innovation around three main areas: (1) databases, (2) machine learning, and (3) automation," said a KeyBanc Capital Markets report by several analysts."While our conversations with customers suggest enterprises continue to shift to a multi-cloud strategy, the pace of AWS innovations, coupled with the breadth of cloud functionality, should continue to sustain high growth for an $18 billion cloud platform," KeyBanc said in a note to clients.IBD'S TAKE: Amazon is an IBD Leaderboard stock with a Composite Rating of 72 out of a possible 99. Amazon.com continues to score new highs, but it's extended from a 1,083.41 buy point.RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney said AWS was releasing new cloud services at a "torrid pace," similar to last year."AWS brought cloud computing mainstream and, while other tech platforms are investing aggressively to catch up, we believe AWS's scale, technical prowess and product vision make it the clear industry leader."Mahaney has an outperform rating on Amazon and a price target of 1,200.Baird analyst Colin Sebastian said in his research note Amazon is beginning to expand its offerings to make machine learning more easily accessible to businesses of all sizes, "which we view as a key driver of increased adoption and further expands Amazon's competitive advantage."Amazon, in October, reported third-quarter results that crushed earnings views and topped revenue estimates as shares took off. Amazon said revenue from Amazon Web Services rose 42% to $4.58 billion, with operating income of $1.17 billion.Amazon, at re:Invent, also announced a new cloud-computing service aimed at helping developers build virtual reality, augmented reality and 3D applications that can run on mobile devices and manage a range of applications.On Wednesday, Amazon said Cyber Monday was the single biggest shopping day in its history, with customers ordering "hundreds of millions of products."RELATED:Amazon Stock Quotes, Company News And Chart AnalysisAmazon Could Be Targeting Pharmacy Delivery Business

Decades of market research shows that the best stocks often have an RS Rating of above 80 in the early stages of their moves.
