Stock futures halved their early gains moving toward Thursday's open following a weak round of September job news. Dow futures held on to a 46.3-point advance. Nasdaq 100 futures traded 10.4 points above fair market value. S&P 500 futures pared back to a 3-point gain.

Some nice gains Wednesday did little to change the fact that the stock market today opens still under the "market in correction" banner. Stronger-than-forecast PMI data out of China lent some positive momentum to global markets.
Stocks in Europe were unevenly positive. London's FTSE 100 climbed 1.3%. The CAC-40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX were up less than 1% near midsession.

Tokyo's Nikkei 225 posted a 1.9% gain, narrowing its loss for the week to less than 1%. China's markets were closed for the country's National Day holiday. The Hong Kong exchange reopens Friday. The Shanghai and Shenzhen markets remain closed through Oct. 7.

U.S. private employers trimmed 58,877 workers from payrolls in September, according to the monthly Job Cuts Report from Challenger, Gray & Christmas. Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) accounted for nearly a third of the 43% increase over August's levels, the report said. Layoffs tied to Target 's (TGT) closing its operations in Canada also boosted the number.
Challenger's total layoff numbers were 93% higher than those of September 2014, giving the third quarter the higher number of quarterly firings since Q3 2009.

Initial jobless claims jumped by 10,000 to 277,000 in the week ended Sept. 26, the Labor Department reported. That outpaced expectations for an increase to 272,000. The four-week moving average inched lower to 270,750 — its fourth straight decline.
The Institute for Supply Management delivers its September manufacturing index, and the Commerce Department reports August construction spending numbers at 10 a.m. ET.
On the Dow, Apple (AAPL) slipped 1% before the open. The iPhone maker gained a bit more than 1% Wednesday, but is down nearly 4% for the week after meeting resistance at its 10-week moving average.

Big oil names gained ground as oil prices bumped up 2%, putting West Texas Intermediate just above $46 a barrel. Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) rose a fraction each. BP (BP) surged nearly 3%. Total (TOT) climbed more than 2%.
Strong early moves deteriorated quickly in the premarket session. An early 6% rebound attempt by Gap (GPS) fizzled to a fractional gain. Foot Locker (FL) saw its early 6% rise flattened.

Among the few that held up, biotech Sarepta Therapeutics (SRPT) vaulted 15% after reporting statistically significant effects from its muscular dystrophy treatment eteplirsen in a clinical phase 2 trial. The stock ended Wednesday 23% off its Sept. 21 high and up 122% for the year.

Verisk Analytics (VRSK) swept up 6% after Standard & Poor's announced late Wednesday the stock would be added to the S&P 500 index, effective Oct. 8. Verisk will replace mining equipment maker Joy Global (JOY), which will be shifted to the S&P midcap 400.
Verisk is hovering below its 10-week moving average in its third consecutive flat base this year. Joy Global shares fell 3% in Thursday's premarket action.

In other markets, the dollar was mixed: up vs. the euro, down on the yen. Bonds edged lower. Most commodities were narrowly mixed.Stock futures halved their early gains moving toward Thursday's open following a weak round of September job news. Dow futures held on to a 46.3-point advance. In a bid to rev up sales following news of a second-quarter slump, Macy's (M) will begin selling merchandise on Alibaba's (BABA) Tmall Global in China later this year.

The nationwide department store said it has formed a joint venture with Hong Kong's Fung Retailing Limited, with plans to bring their e-commerce pilot to Alibaba's online marketplace. Shoppers will be able to pay for their purchases using Alipay, a mobile payment system akin to Apple (AAPL) Pay.
During the post-earnings conference call, Macy's management said it has no plans to open brick-and-mortar stores in China, but would consider it in the future, according to Reuters.
The move is just one of Macy's sales growth initiatives, which include expanding same-day delivery to more markets, and opening off-price stores and 10 more Bluemercury beauty and spa locations.

During the quarter, earnings fell 20% to 64 cents a share, well below analyst forecasts for 76 cents per share. Revenue dipped almost 3% to $6.1 billion, missing views for $6.23 billion. Management blamed internal and macroeconomic factors for Q2 weakness.
"In the second quarter, we removed a major Friends & Family promotional event from Macy's calendar," said CEO Terry Lundgren.

"In addition, as a result of the previous port slowdown, planned markdowns in many departments were delayed into the second quarter to clear merchandise that arrived late. Moreover, throughout the first half of the year, overall consumer demand has been restrained in many of the categories of merchandise we sell, and the strong U.S. dollar has led to significantly lower international tourist spending."
Shares closed down 5.1% to 64.11 in the stock market today.
Lackluster sales prompted Macy's to cut its full-year same-store sales. It now expects flat comps vs. previous guidance for 2% growth.
The company trimmed full-year sales growth to a decline of 1%, down from prior outlook for growth of 1%. It sees per-share earnings of $4.70 to $4.80.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect 0.7% revenue growth to $28.29 billion and $4.67 in per-share earnings for the year.

Macy's also said Wednesday that it will sell part of its nine-story Fulton Street property in downtown Brooklyn to Tishman Speyer, following reports in June that the department store was feeling pressure to let go of some of its real estate. Macy's said it will receive $170 million in cash for the assets, plus an additional $100 million over the next three years for renovations.
Alibaba disclosed results Wednesday as well, missing Q1 revenue estimates.
Expect other department stores to report this week. Kohl's (KSS) reports before the open Thursday. Nordstrom (JWN) reports Q2 results after the close Thursday.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.

Retailers delivered a poor report card for the height of the back-to-school selling season, posting August sales that missed views as shoppers remained cautious amid changing spending patterns. August sales at stores open at least a year slipped 1% vs. a year earlier, said Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics, in a Thursday report. Analysts expected a 0.6% decline. Costco…
Stocks traded narrowly mixed going into the lunch hour Thursday, but energy stocks were lower as oil tumbled to a six-year low.

The Nasdaq rose less than 0.1%; the S&P 500 fell less than 0.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average was down slightly in the stock market today. Volume on both exchanges was tracking significantly lower than Wednesday's levels.

Energy-related industry groups were the day's poorest performers. West Texas intermediate touched a six-year low as it closed in on $42 a barrel. Analysts said worries over a global economic slowdown, growing supplies and a refinery outage in Indiana combined to drop prices by 2%.
Diamondback Energy (FANG) dropped 3% after pricing a 2.5 million-share offering at 70.24 a share.
Airlines outperformed again, but troubled Copa Holdings (CPA) fell 12% after reporting disappointing Q2 earnings and sales.
GoPro (GPRO) rose 5% after Cowen & Co. analyst Robert Stone started coverage with an outperform rating. He said new software should make their products easier to use.

Tesla Motors (TSLA) rallied 3%. It said it will sell $500 million in stock to fund projects like the Model 3 and the Nevada battery factory. The stock dropped 9% Aug. 6 after posting disappointing quarterly report. The company has reported three straight quarters of losses. Analysts predict the company will lose 30 cents a share this year, but post big profits in 2016.
Shake Shack (SHAK) gapped down and was trading 9% lower after pricing an offering of 4 million shares at 60 a share.

Macy's (M) shares perked up after Starboard Value's Jeffrey Smith reportedly disclosed that he has taken a position in the department store chain and thinks the stock could be worth over 125 a share, nearly twice its current price.Shares rose 5.8% to 70.61 in the stock market today.At the Delivering Alpha investor's conference in New York City, co-hosted by CNBC and Institutional Investor, the activist investor noted Macy's real estate value, and said the company could split up its real estate and retail businesses."We believe there is an opportunity to create two leading companies . . . while maintaining the dividend," Smith reportedly said, according to CNBC's live blog of the event.On Monday, Macy's said it had sold its 1.2 million-square-foot downtown Pittsburgh property to Core Realty. Cowen & Co. analyst Oliver Chen said he believes the sale, worth $15 million, "signifies (management's) willingness to sell properties for the right price."In a July 6 note, Chen noted that "In our view, M has greatest potential to unlock real estate value (est. $19B), but large-scale event unlikely given complexity, control loss & higher rents."Reports emerged in early June that the company was under some investor pressure to consider its real estate options.Fellow department store Nordstrom (JWN) shares rose 0.8% to 78.65. J.C. Penney (JCP) rose 1.2% to 9.11. Retailers headed into the back-to-school selling season posting soft sales gains as unseasonably hot weather dampened apparel sales and consumers remained cautious in their spending amid worries over their future buying power. The lackluster results send a signal that retailers may have some tough going during the key back-to-school buying period, which started in late July and runs through mid-September.…

Lower gas prices finally may be translating into people feeling a little more willing to open their wallets as analysts predict consumer discretionary companies to be leaders in the second quarter's earnings season. Consumer discretionary retailers, which comprise about 17% of the overall Standard & Poor's 500, are expected to deliver 7.2% earnings growth in Q2 compared to a year…

Stocks remained deep in the red going into the last hour of trading as rate-hike concerns and falling commodity prices continued to weigh. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 1%, the S&P 500 shed 0.8%, and the Nasdaq was down 0.6%. Volume was higher across the board in the stock market today, vs. the same time Wednesday.
St. Louis Fed President James Bullard said in a speech earlier today that the Fed should start hiking interest rates based on "prudence alone."

Auto parts retailers, nonalcoholic beverage makers and energy stocks, weighed down by falling crude oil prices, were among the biggest losers. Gainers included department stores, software and apparel stocks.

Kohl's (KSS) gapped up and rose 6% in busy trade, recovering most of its prior-session loss. The department store operator, which fell nearly 6% Wednesday, reported Q3 earnings, revenue and same-store sales above views.

Dillard's (DDS) was up 4%, while Nordstrom (JWN) and Macy's (M) climbed 2% each. On Wednesday, these stocks fell 8%, 4% and 14%, respectively, after Macy's revealed disappointing sales and lowered guidance. At least four analysts cut their Macy's price targets Thursday, but Cowen & Co. raised its price target.

Ten IBD 50 names were up, led by NetEase (NTES), which rose 3% to clear a 154.98 buy point in heavy volume after reporting better-than-expected Q3 results.. TAL Education Group (XRS) and LinkedIn (LNKD) each gained 2% in above-average trade.

Chinese online retailer JD.com (JD) surged 4% in volume after reporting a 130% increase in Singles' Day sales from last year. Singles' Day, which occurred Wednesday, is the biggest shopping day of the year in China. JD.com's chief rival Alibaba (BABA), which also scored record sales for the day, was slightly lower.

Stocks strengthened in early afternoon trading Wednesday, with Internet retail stocks leading the way and brick-and-mortar department stores in the rear.The Nasdaq rose 0.4%. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average poked into positive territory, up 0.1% each in the stock market today. Volume was lower on both exchanges.TAL Education (XRS) rose 3%, hitting a new high in above-average volume. It broke out of a late-stage, cup-with-handle base with a 38.75 buy point Tuesday. The company provides after-school tutoring in China.Big-cap Internet retail stocks were strong, with the industry group rising 1.3%. Alphabet (GOOGL) hit a new high and was up 1%. It's extended after gapping out of a base Oct. 23 on an earnings report.Department stores were the worst-performing group, down nearly 7%. Macy's (M) gapped down and was trading 14% lower. Sales missed estimates and Macy's cut its forecast for the rest of the year. It said it will close more stores and won't form a real estate investment trust.Citi Investment Research analyst Paul Lejuez said warmer weather caused fewer people to buy winter clothes like boots and coats in the third quarter. Kohl's (KSS) also dropped nearly 7%, and Urban Outfitters (URBN) fell 6%. It's now at its lowest level since 2012.Follow Ken Hoover on Twitter @IBD_KHoover.

Fitbit (FIT) stock went on a post-Thanksgiving turkey trot on Monday after getting an analyst upgrade. Barclays analyst Matthew McClintock on Monday upgraded Fitbit stock to overweight from equal weight with a price target of 49. Fitbit was up more than 2.5%, near 28.50, in afternoon trading on the stock market today.Fitbit, the top maker of activity trackers and fitness bands, went public on June 18 at 20. It climbed as high as 51.90 on Aug. 5 before investors got vertigo. Its shares tumbled on concerns about increased competition and profit erosion.Fitbit's recent stock decline is unwarranted, McClintock said in a research report. The company has "meaningful catalysts" ahead including holiday season sales, the CES trade show, new product launches and corporate wellness deals, he said."Considering that Fitbit is the fastest-growing meaningful consumer company in the world at 140%+ revenue year over year in 2015 (in a world lacking true growth stories), we believe the current valuation levels are just too compelling to ignore," he said.Wearables appear to be one of the winning product categories this holiday and Fitbit is the brand of choice, according to retail channel checks, he said. Plus, Fitbit was less discounted than its peers over the Black Friday weekend, McClintock said.Retailers Best Buy (BBY), Target (TGT) and Kohl's (KSS) cited strong wearable device sales in recent reports."We estimate that Fitbit can grow annual revenue by at least 40% over the next several years, which could ultimately prove conservative (our upside case is for Fitbit to grow revenue almost 70% over the next several years)," McClintock said. "Our estimates for revenue growth are entirely driven by overall category growth/consumer adoption as well as geographic expansion (Fitbit's global operations currently represent less than 25% of sales)."Pacific Crest Securities analyst Brad Erickson said his retail channel checks on Black Friday indicated soft in-store fitness tracker sales. However, online sales may have offset weaker brick-and-mortar sales.Fitbit saw "slightly disappointing in-store demand," Erickson said in a report Sunday."Our checks indicate that wearable devices overall, and Fitbit specifically, underperformed store expectations on Black Friday, driven by strong Apple Watch sales and a likely channel shift toward online," he said. "Historically, Fitbit has done as much as 40% of its sales through online channels, and we think this holiday could index above those levels. So while we're noting the in-store feedback as a modest negative, we're not ruling out that the fitness category's likely higher proclivity toward online channels may have provided Fitbit some offset to this softness."Erickson rates Fitbit stock as overweight with a price target of 47.Fitbit likely didn't see any meaningful market share loss to rival activity trackers from Garmin (GRMN) and others over Black Friday weekend, he said. But Apple 's (AAPL) Apple Watch smartwatch, which was discounted by some retailers, could have impacted wearables demand, he said.RELATED:Fitbit, Apple Watch demand up ahead of holidaysFitbit takes ill as secondary stock offer cuts value.
Continuing last week's spate of retail disappointments, shares of Dillard's (DDS) closed down 6% after the department store chain missed earnings and revenue forecasts for the third quarter.
Earnings fell 8.5% to $1.19 per share, short of consensus views by a penny, as revenue dropped 1.8% to $1.47 billion. Analysts had expected $1.49 billion in sales.
Same-store sales fell 4% in Q3.

Shoes, juniors' and kids' apparel, cosmetics and ladies' apparel were the better-performing categories, said the company, while men's apparel and accessories and ladies' accessories and lingerie, as well as home and furniture, were weaker.

As retailers find themselves in the midst of the holiday quarter, the mounting concerns are that this important shopping season will yield lighter results than hoped. October retail sales from the Commerce Department fell short of expectations last week with a mere 0.1% gain, while Amazon (AMZN) and other online retailers logged a 7.1% climb.
Fellow department stores Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN) offered grim results and cut forecasts last week, and even retailers that topped Wall Street estimates fell sharply.
J.C. Penney (JCP) shares lost over 15% Friday even after coming out ahead of views, and Kohl's (KSS) has quickly given up gains from its Thursday consensus beat.
Kohl's stock rose 2.5% Monday afternoon, and J.C. Penney gained 2.55%. Amazon rallied 0.85%.
Macy's shares fell 1.2%, while Nordstrom rose 1.4%.
More retailers report this week, with Wal-Mart (WMT) and T.J. Maxx and Marshalls parent TJX (TJX) on tap for Tuesday, and Target (TGT) and Ross Stores (ROST) report later in the week.
RELATED:
Will TJX, Target Survive Amid Crushed Retail Stocks?

Interest-rate jitters were back on the front burner near midday Thursday as stocks traded firmly in negative territory.

The Dow Jones industrial average underperformed, falling 0.8%, weighed down by Caterpillar (CAT), Chevron (CVX) and Goldman Sachs (GS). The S&P 500 lost 0.7%, and the Nasdaq eased 0.4%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking well above Wednesday's levels in the stock market today.
On the NYSE, declining stocks outnumbered advancers by 3-to-1. The ratio was about 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
In speeches earlier today, St. Louis Fed President James Bullard and Richmond Fed President Jeffrey Lacker made comments that put a rate hike at the December meeting on the front burner again.

Department store operators rallied after Wednesday's drubbing, but it looked more like a dead-cat bounce. Positive sentiment was fueled by better-than-expected earnings and sales from Kohl's (KSS) before the open. Kohl's jumped nearly 7%, but it's still 42% off its recent high.

On the downside, auto parts retailer Advance Auto Parts (AAP) plunged 13% after reporting weak earnings and issuing sluggish guidance. For 2015, it now sees earnings of $7.75 to $7.90 a share, from $8.10 to $8.30, due to costs related to its acquisition of General Parts International for $2 billion. The deal closed in January 2014.
Early winners in the IBD 50 included NetEase (NTES), LinkedIn (LNKD), Noah Holdings (NOAH) and Paycom (PAYC).
December crude oil futures fell 60 cents, or 1.4%, to $42.33 a barrel, near a 2 1/2-month low. Copper shed another 2% to a six-year low.

Department store stocks got slammed Monday as JPMorgan said that Macy's (M), Nordstrom (JWN), Kohl's (KSS) and Dillard's (DDS) have too much cold-weather inventory. Also Monday, Citigroup cut its price targets on Macy's and Kohl's, saying that weak traffic trends and warm weather likely affected sales in the third quarter. And with elevated inventory, department stores are facing a "challenging"…

In addition to their belt-loosening Thanksgiving feasts, top executives at Alphabet (GOOGL), Netflix (NFLX), Goldman Sachs (GS), Facebook (FB) and Visa (V) fattened their wallets, thanks to them selling their own companies' stock.  Under Armour (UA) founder, Chairman and CEO Kevin Plank on Monday announced the planned sale of 450,000 shares for $41.4 million. The athletic wear company's shares…

Black Friday is nearly upon us, and the National Retail Federation says that 136 million Americans plan to shop on Thanksgiving weekend.According to Cowen & Co., there will be deeper promotions this year amid elevated cold-weather apparel inventory and pricing investments by retailers.Cowen says most early promos are online as retailers try to gain "mindshare" earlier versus their peers and compete against Amazon (AMZN), Target (TGT), Kohl's (KSS) and Best Buy (BBY) are among big-box stores who've been running early promos.As consumers become more savvy and sophisticated, there's less need for standing in line waiting for in-store deals. Cowen says these Black Friday "doorbusters" are losing their appeal.Even still, retailers from Wal-Mart (WMT) to Macy's (M) to JCPenney (JCP) are opening their doors on Thanksgiving Day in anticipation of the traditional holiday shopping rush.Amazon shares rose 0.6% on the stock market today, close to Monday's record high. Target rose 0.4%, Wal-Mart 0.5%, Best Buy 1.3% and Macy's 1.9%. Kohl's dipped 0.1% and JCPenney 0.4%.Follow Alissa Williams on Twitter @IBD_AWilliams and Facebook.

Never mind "Let It Snow." Heading into the crucial holiday shopping season, retailers are more likely singing "Let It Go" from the movie "Frozen" as they try to shake off disappointing quarterly earnings results and a bad week that collectively sank merchant stocks.Nordstrom (JWN), Macy 's (M), J.C. Penney Co. (JCP) and Kohl's (KSS) were among those that reported the week of Nov. 9, with Nordstrom and Macy's turning in weak results and discounted forecasts, and J.C. Penney and Kohl's shares falling despite beating consensus views.An October retail sales data miss — a worse-than-expected 0.1% gain — didn't help either, though Amazon (AMZN) and other e-commerce sellers notably logged a 7.1% rise from the previous year as consumers continue to do much of their shopping online. Cowen & Co. predicted in July that Amazon would knock out Macy's as the top U.S. apparel retailer by 2017.Even much-lauded off-pricers haven't been immune to the pummeling that retail stocks were subjected to over the past week. Shares of TJX (TJX), the parent company of T.J. Maxx, Marshalls and HomeGoods, lost 12% over the past week.In a possible sign of things to come, Q3 same-store sales at Nordstrom's off-price arm, Nordstrom Rack, fell 2.2%."This type of miss from Rack is surprising to us, and we acknowledge the Rack's off-price slowdown could be a negative indicator for TJX," wrote Cowen & Co. analyst Oliver Chen on Friday.But he added that TJX, which reports Tuesday, could "offset some secular weakness" based on a few factors, including the strength of the company's sourcing and buying teams, home goods offerings and international reach.The company is expected to report a slight earnings dip of 1% to 84 cents a share. That would mark the third straight quarter of earnings deceleration and a swing from earnings gains of 7%, 8% and 15% in the three preceding periods.Revenue is seen rising 5% to $7.73 million, which also would reflect a slowdown.With a 75 IBD Composite Rating, TJX is the highest ranking member of IBD's Retail-Apparel/Shoes/Accessories group, which ranks a feeble 144 out of 197 groups.Peers in the group include Ross Stores, Foot Locker (FL), L Brands (LB) and American Eagle Outfitters (AEO).Fellow off-pricer Ross Stores (ROST) gapped down ahead of its Thursday earnings release, losing 11% for the week. Analysts expect over 6% EPS growth to 50 cents on 6% sales growth to $2.77 billion.And what about the big-box retailers?Target's (TGT) earnings are seen accelerating, with a predicted 59% climb to 86 cents a share on a 1% revenue dip to $17.57 billion. Shares retreated 6.9% last week.And Wall Street expects Wal-Mart (WMT) earnings to slide 15% to 98 cents a share on a 1% revenue decline to $117.79 billion. Shares slid 4%."We believe retail is in a state of transition as brands wrestle with how to compete against growing & dynamic pureplay online retailers," wrote Chen.RELATED:Retail Sales Weak, Except For Amazon, EcommerceMacy's Stock Selloff Could Be Tip Of Iceberg4 Reasons TJX, Off-Price Retailers Will Keep Surging.

Retail ETFs fell hard Friday as Nordstrom (JWN) and Fossil (FOSL) disappointed investors already grappling with Macy's (M) grim results and outlook. October retail sales data, released today, did little to lift the spirits.
The markets sold off broadly, with ETFs tracking major indexes closing at session lows.
J.C. Penney (JCP) reported a sales beat before the market open, but the stock tumbled 15% amid broader retail woes.
Nordstrom, the upscale department store, plunged 15% on the stock market today.
Fossil, the watch and fashion accessories company, sank 37%.
Macy's fell 4%.
Even Kohl's (KSS) reversed, diving 7% despite an earnings beat Thursday that saw the stock gap up to briefly retake its 50-day line.
Retailers' woes rippled across the consumer discretionary sector. IBD Leaderboard stock Starbucks (SBUX) slipped 2% and posted its third consecutive weekly loss.
The retail-restaurant industry group is currently ranked 114 out of 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. Department stores rank 193, the worst among retail groups. Internet retail ranks best at No. 4.

Consumer Discretionary Select SDPR (XLY), the largest ETF holding retail, restaurant and related stocks, tumbled 2.7%, finishing near the bottom of the day's range. It was the hardest hit of 11 Select Sector SDPR ETFs holding S&P 500 stocks.
XLY holds 89 stocks, with Amazon.com (AMZN) its largest holding at 11% portfolio weighting. It also holds Starbucks and fast-food giant McDonald's (MCD).
The ETF is 5% off its 52-week high of 81.87, set Nov. 4. It bagged a 5% weekly loss, giving up its gains over the past month.
SPDR S&P Retail (XRT), which focuses more exclusively on general merchandisers, drug stores, grocery stores and apparel stores, fell 3.8%.
The ETF holds 102 equal-weighted stocks and is 17% off its old high. Amazon is among its holdings.
XRT is down 11% year to date through Thursday vs. a 9% gain for XLY.
Gold continues to lose its shine. Gold ETFs hit their lowest point in the past year Thursday.
Weekly Update
SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) posted its fourth weekly loss, declining 0.5%. The ETF is 17% off its January high.

Major U.S. stock indexes snapped six straight weeks of gains. ETFs tracking the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial indexes breached their 200-day moving averages as the market direction shifted to uptrend under pressure. That calls for a cautious approach from ETF investors.
Among sectors, utilities eked out a 0.7% weekly gain. Every other S&P 500 sector finished in the red for the week. Energy was gouged nearly 6%.

Plunging energy prices sent the stock market into a tailspin in afternoon trading Thursday.The Nasdaq was down 0.4%, while the S&P 500 dropped 0.8% and the Dow Jones industrial average bore the brunt of the damage, off 1% in the stock market today.Volume was tracking higher than the same time Wednesday on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq exchanges.Oil prices turned tail and were trading nearly 3% lower, well below $42 a barrel. OPEC said that crude oil stockpiles stood at 210 million barrels in the developed world, above the five-year average.St. Louis Fed President James Bullard said that the central bank should raise interest rates because emergency policies are no longer necessary with the labor market and inflation near the Fed's goals.Among Dow 30 stocks, 28 were lower, led by Caterpillar (CAT), Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM), all down nearly 3%.Among IBD 50 stocks, eight were higher and 42 were lower. The worst performer was LGI Homes (LGIH), down 4%, but it remained above its 50-day moving average.The best performer was NetEase (NTES), which broke out of a cup base with a 154.98 buy point. Volume was massive, but the stock was trading in the lower half of its daily range and having trouble holding the buy point. It was up 3%.Among industry groups, energy, machinery and miners were among the worst performers on the day.Department stores were the top-performing groups. Kohl's (KSS) rose 5% after a cheery earnings report. But a disappointing Macy's (M) report on Wednesday sent the whole group deeper into a correction.

Stocks were narrowly mixed going into the last hour of the regular trading session. The Nasdaq held a gain of less than 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average each dipped less than 0.1%.
Volume was narrowly higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq.
Losers outpaced winners by 7-to-5 on the NYSE and 3-to-2 on the Nasdaq.

Telecom, Internet retail and building-related stocks were among top gainers in the stock market today. LGI Homes (LGIH) led the IBD 50 with a 5% gain, extending its bounce off the 50-day moving average. LGI, which earns a 99 Composite Rating, is one of the stocks in the homebuilder group.

Amazon.com (AMZN) advanced 2%, marking a record best in twice normal trade. The stock is extended 22% from a 549.88 buy point cleared Oct. 23. Morgan Stanley raised its price target on the online retail giant to 800 from 750.

IBD 50 stock Alphabet (GOOGL) rose to an intraday high, up 1%. Shares are 7% past a 713.43 buy point they broke out past, also on Oct. 23. MKM Partners boosted its price target on the Google parent to 945 from 805.

Autobytel (ABTL) soared 5% in fast trade. The stock is well extended past a 19.66 double-bottom buy point initially cleared Oct. 5. It vaulted 10% Nov. 6 after reporting Q3 results the prior day. The online automotive website shares a 99 Composite Rating in the top-ranked Internet content group with Alphabet, Facebook (FB) and LinkedIn (LNKD).

Department stores, energy and apparel stocks underperformed. Macy's (M) gapped down and sank nearly 14% in heavy volume after reporting disappointing sales and cutting its full-year earnings and sales guidance. Among other department store retailers, Dillard's (DDS) fell 7%, Kohl's (KSS) 5% and Nordstrom (JWN) 3%, all in busy trade.

Macy's (M) reported a third straight quarterly decline in sales early Wednesday, prompting it to slash its full-year profit and sales forecasts, and sending shares crashing early Wednesday. The company also forecast a decline in same-store sales for the fourth quarter, raising concerns about holiday prospects for the venerable department store chain. Macy's shares tumbled 13.5% in midday trading on…

Consumer sentiment unexpectedly fell for a third straight month in March, according to the latest University of Michigan survey, as Americans suspect that the era of cheap gas is ending. That's a bad sign for consumer spending from Apple (AAPL) iPhones to Tiffany (TIF) jewelry.The Michigan sentiment index's flash reading was 90, down 1.7 points from the February's final reading of 91.7, January's 92 and December's 92.6. It's the lowest reading since October. Wall Street expected a flash March reading on 92.2.The index hit 95.9 in April, the highest since January 2007, but quickly retreated to 87.2 in September.The survey measures consumers' attitudes toward current economic conditions and future expectations. The current conditions gauge fell 1.2 points to 105.6, while an expectations measure declined 1.9 points to 80."Consumer confidence eased in early March due to increased concerns about prospects for the economy as well as the expectation that gas prices would inch upward during the year ahead," said Richard Curtin, the survey's chief economist.But the connection between consumer confidence and consumer spending isn't always clear.Retail sales have fallen in the first two months of 2016. Much of that reflects cheaper gasoline, but shoppers haven't rushed to spend the extra cash. Electronics sales have retreated, with Apple iPhone sales declining this quarter and Apple Watch sales failing to excite. (Apple may hope for some sales boost as it reveals new products, including a new smaller phone at Monday's product event.)Auto sales have held up well, but General Motors (GM) and Ford Motor (F) remain down for the year and below their 200-day moving averages. GM, Ford and other automakers increasingly have relied on subprime and ever-longer long terms to boost demand, while cheap gas has fueled low-mileage, high-margin SUV sales.Meanwhile, Kohl's (KSS) issued a big profit warning, while Macy's (M) has shut some stores. But the Retail-Department Stores stock group has been one of IBD's strongest industry groups so far in 2016.Tiffany shares rose 2.1% in afternoon trade on the stock market today after the luxury jeweler reported declining earnings that still topped views. But Tiffany warned of more weak profit ahead, as tourists spend less.The rebounding stock market could fuel consumer spending, at least among higher-income households with large portfolios.

Are department store chains sitting ducks in the new retailing jungle of the Amazon.com (AMZN)?It seems that in 2016 so far, bullish investors would disagree.IBD's Retail-Department Stores industry group has a trashy rating for six-month relative price performance -- at No. 158 out of 197 groups and subgroups as of Thursday's newspaper. Yet the group is also up more than 10% since Jan. 1. Only four other groups, including Food-Meat and Mining-Gold, can match that performance.What's more, a positive trend within the Retail sector is emerging; five more retail subgroups -- discount & variety, leisure products, apparel and shoes, restaurants and auto parts -- show year-to-date gains of 3% or more. The S&P 500 is down 5%.Macy's (M) has the largest market cap in Retail-Department Stores at $13.6 billion. The 37 RS Rating is wretched. Yet the stock is up more than 23% since Jan. 1. Even with the stout gains, Macy's is still 41% below its 52-week peak of 73.61.Macy's continues to see slumping sales; in the past four quarters, they fell 1%, 3%, 5% and 5% below year-ago levels. Yet the big box retailer is still profitable; Wall Street sees earnings in fiscal 2017 (ending in January next year) slipping only 3% to $3.80 a share. That's still sharply above the $1.29 it pocketed in fiscal 2009 amid the Great Recession.Macy's has mastered the practice of making every week feel like Black Friday. Customers are bombarded with big-discount coupons nearly every week via email, the Sunday paper or by snail mail. It seems to be working. Its one-day Saturday Sale events have brought loyal customers into its cavernous stores.Macy's strives for innovation; on Feb. 18 it unveiled a new line of men's clothing with snowboarding and skateboard superstar Shaun White. The collection pledges to reflect White's "adrenaline-pumping, eclectic style."Macy's has driven its annual pretax margin to the 7% to 8% level over the past five years, up from the 3% to 5% range seen from 2008 to 2011.Nordstrom (JWN), No. 2 in market cap at $9.6 billion, has rebounded in recent days following its Q4 report of a fifth quarter in a row of declining EPS (-11% to $1.17, despite a 4% pickup in sales) and is up more than 5% year-to-date. Watch to see if the stock can climb back near its 200-day moving average, near 63 for now.Kohl's (KSS)  ($8.7 bil market cap) and Dillard's (DDS) ($3 bil), both forecast to grow FY 2017 profit by 6%, are also struggling to regain their long-term 200-day moving averages.

Warmer-than-expected weather hit Kohl's (KSS) and Sears Holdings (SHLD) results in the holiday quarter, while Kohl's said it will pilot a new, smaller-format concept this year.Kohl's fourth-quarter earnings fell 14% to $1.58 a share, 2 cents above views. Revenue nudged up 0.8% to $6.39 billion, more or less in line with estimates. Same-store sales grew 0.4%, missing estimates. The holidays were strong, said management, but softness in November and January weighed on comp growth. The company had logged 3.7% comps during the prior-year quarter.On Wednesday, it declared an 11% dividend hike to 50 cents a share.For 2016, it expects diluted EPS of $4.05 to $4.25 and total sales ranging from a 0.5% decline to 0.5% growth. Analysts expect 1% sales growth to $19.41 billion for the year."Is flat growth the new norm for department stores?" asked Cowen & Co. analyst Oliver Chen in a Thursday note on Kohl's.Many retailers such as Kohl's and Macy's are now exploring off-price offerings as they aim to compete with TJX (TJX) and Ross Stores (ROST), leaders in the off-price space.Kohl's said it will close 18 underperforming stores this year -- less than 1% of total sales -- and has plans to open seven new, smaller-format stores around the country as part of a pilot program. It will also open two additional off-price Off/Aisle pilot stores in Wisconsin.Shares closed up 2.7% in the stock market today.Macy's (M), which bested expectations when it reported Tuesday, closed 40 stores and opened 26 in fiscal 2015, also announcing plans to open 15 off-price Backstage locations inside Macy's stores this year.Meanwhile, Sears reported Thursday a wider-than-expected loss of $1.70 vs. views for a $1.36 per-share loss. Revenue fell 10% to $7.3 billion, slightly above estimates for $7.26 billion.Kmart comps fell 7.2%. Sears Domestic comps declined 6.9%.Shares rose 3.2%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Discount giant Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) and high-end department store operator Nordstrom (JWN) will likely report yet another quarter of weaker earnings over the holiday season. And sales won't be so hot either.The 2015 holiday quarter was tough sledding for many retailers. Abnormally warm weather kept shelves bulging with cold-weather goods at many retailers, leading to heavy markdowns that hurt margins. Another drawback: The ongoing shift to online shopping and growing competition from e-commerce giants like Amazon (AMZN) led to a slowdown in traffic at the malls.Friday's retail sales report showed January purchases rose 0.2%. But while Amazon and nonstore retailers reported a 1.5% jump, department store sales slid 0.8%. Earlier this month, Kohl's (KSS) issued a big warning, sending its shares down 19% on Feb. 4. (Amazon, for its part, crashed 16% over five sessions after its 122% EPS gain failed to reach even-loftier expectations.)There are no such lofty expectations for Wal-Mart. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Wal-Mart to see an 11% decline in adjusted earnings from a year earlier to $1.43 a share when it reports Thursday before the open. Much of that expected EPS slide is "attributable to increased labor costs," Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics, said in a report on Q4 retail earnings.This would be the sixth straight EPS decline for Wal-Mart, though smaller than its Q3 drop of 14%. Still, analysts expect weaker profits for the next four quarters as well.Wal-Mart's earnings have been under pressure due to costs from boosting wages, watchers say.Last month, the giant discounter announced more than 1.2 million Wal-Mart U.S. and Sam’s Club associates will receive a pay increase under the second phase of the company’s two-year, $2.7 billion investment in workers. The pay raise, which takes effect Feb. 20, will be "one of the largest single-day, private-sector pay increases ever," Wal-Mart said in a statement.All associates hired before Jan. 1, 2016, will earn at least $10 per hour. New entry-level associates will continue to start at $9 per hour and move to at least $10 an hour after successfully completing the company’s new retail skills and training program known as Pathways, the company said.Also last month, the company said it will close 154 locations in the U.S., including the company’s 102 smallest format stores, Walmart Express, which had been in pilot since 2011.Analysts expect Wal-Mart's Q4 revenue to slip 0.6% from a year earlier to $130.75 billion. That would be less than the decrease the company saw in Q3. U.S. same-store sales have risen for the past several quarters.Wal-Mart shares rose 1.3% on the stock market Friday, finding resistance near the 200-day moving average.Analysts forecast Nordstrom will see Q4 earnings slip 7% from a year earlier to $1.22 a share when it reports results Thursday after the close. That would be less than the 22% earnings decline in Q3. But it would be the fifth straight quarter of EPS declines -- with the streak continuing for the next three quarters.Analysts see sales rising 4.5% to $4.224 billion.While Nordstrom is an upscale retailer, much of its growth has been in its off-price (but not cheap) Nordstrom Rack chain.Nordstrom just unveiled the footprint and exterior design of its first Nordstrom store in New York City. The store will encompass four properties in the Columbus Circle neighborhood in Manhattan. The approximately 363,000 square-foot store is expected to open in 2019.Nordstrom stock fell 0.6% on Friday.

BOOOOOMMMMMM! The mkt had another rough but interesting day…..yesterday...... S&P futures were originally up – small, but up…. then after the rash of more disappointing macro data hit the tape at 8:30 am – you could feel the air pressure change……Challenger Job Cuts – soar! US companies announced 75k job CUTS last month – that is up 200% over December and up 42% from one year ago! Initial jobless claims higher, continuing claims higher, and then the retailers HIT.....Kohl's ( (KSS)) and Ralph Lauren ( (RL)) shocked the mkts with very disappointing earnings and sales figures for December and guidance for the new year…. This is where the concern about the consumer hits you right between the eyeballs....Remember all the chatter last fall - How great the shopping season was going to be, how the consumer was flush with cash, how the tide had turned and retailers were going to be the beneficiaries??? Does any of that ring a bell?Futures did a complete 180 and fell out bed……the pressure was mounting – the storm clouds were building….….

RL & KSS and every other retailer was for sale – The DMM (Designated Market Maker) in RL struggled to find bids as the sellers poured in……Sell 20k , then 50k, then 100k – buyers were not be found anywhere in line...…as the sellers get anxious – the buyers recoiled even more…..The stock was indicated down $10, then $12 then $15 as brokers worked to gather interest……then at 9:29:55 the bell began to ring – Ding, ding, ding, ding, ding…… and we're OFF......Stocks began to open, the indices began to reflect the concern as the pressure mounted.....volume surges as the action gets under way......The stock (RL) opened at $103.27 (down $12) and then proceeded to trade down another $15 (to $88) in the mins after as SELLERS (mostly those liquidity providers) came out of the woodwork.....hitting any bid available........The issue now?: The intuitional buyers weren't standing there willing to get run over - so with the guidance of their brokers they moved lower until the selling subsided and the stock found support……The volume exploded in this issue as we traded some 10.8 mil shares vs. the average daily volume of 2.2 mil shares. What had happened? Nothing really – it was just another day in an anxious, nervous, automated, volatile mkt…. where investors are convinced that someone is playing "I got a secret!".And then - CNBC runs with the story – The one everyone 'isn't talking about' BUT should be....…Wink, Wink! The one that Ron Insana forced us to address on Tuesday....
"Negative Rates in the US? Here's Why It Could Happen"

In this expose by Jeff Cox – he makes it very clear that the next move for US interest rates may be down and not up…..and he goes so far to say that down means going to the dark side - Yes folks - get ready for negative rates… and the reasons are many as WE all know - but apparently not to many in DC know - so let me highlight just a few: Building recession fears in the US, unstable financial mkts, currency devaluations by some ‘emerging mkt' countries, weakening global macro data, collapsing oil and commodity prices and pressure from other central banks that have already moved towards negative rates.Jeff points out that while it may seem highly unlikely – "Snow White and the 10 dwarfs' would have to consider the possibility of going to the dark side "should financial conditions tighten and threats to economic growth increase." BankAmerica rates strategist – Mark Cabana echoes that sentiment saying: "While not our baseline scenario, if the U.S. economy were to sufficiently weaken we believe the Fed could consider negative rates as a means to ease policy,"So I must ask – How could we go from being so strong 6 weeks ago – as indicated by the FED in December, when they raised rates citing 'explosive growth'....which was then echoed by the President in January – to being so weak so quickly? I mean just last week – Vice Chair Stanley Fischer told us that "4 more rates hikes were in the ballpark for 2016" – and Wednesday KC Pres Ester George – backed him up!So what gives? Did he mean that ‘4 more rate DECREASES were in the ballpark for 2016?' I mean Fischer is 72 yrs old – maybe he was just confused…..I mean we all know that Greenspan (now 90) was most definitely confused/borderline stunata (Sicilian for nuts) during his tenure at the FED – because this whole mess – I mean THIS WHOLE MESS started under his watch….(but that's a story for another day).

So - we must consider the possibility that Cousin Stanley was confused…..In the end – the broad mkt fell 15 pts to 1900, then rallied 27 pts to 1927 only to fail again and then rally again into the close to end the day at 1915 or up 2.92. Oil also had a bit of nutty day…..trading in a 5% range – initially +3% then falling 1.7% by days' end. And all of this makes sense – remember – the mkt has suffered some real damage of late – trading well below any support levels as it thrashes around trying to build a base amid deteriorating macro reports...... Add in all the global geo-political issues and you can see why the mkt is struggling.The Fed is trying desperately to stay calm and hold the mkt steady…..and to do this – they MUST keep crude oil prices from moving lower so how do they do that? Well given the relationship between oil prices and the US dollar, the Fed has been very actively JAWBONING (see yesterday's note) the dollar lower by floating the idea of negative US interest rates. By doing so – they manage to create some demand for gold – which has rallied nicely – since the December lows. The China Yuan devaluation and the threat of more to come coupled with the Japanese move to the dark side – (negative rates) – saw Gold react beautifully as many investors embrace it as the safest haven of all. As of yesterday – it has now managed to pierce all 3 resistance levels – the 50, 100 and 200 day moving averages – which now sets it up for a run….Look for it to test the October highs of $1185/oz and if we blow thru that - then a run to $1250 is clearly a possibility. Back to the FED – Who is kidding who? Rates are not going any higher at all….not now, not in March and not in the summer….at most – the FED will return us to a zero rate policy – because in the end – negative rates suggest desperation, no matter how you slice it. You CAN'T possibly argue that negative rates are just another ‘tool in the toolbox' ....They are the nuclear option....not a place I want to be.Overnight Asian mkts were essentially lower.....no significant news to report - other than more speculation about what China has up their sleeve and what the FED has up her sleeve.....Japan -1.23%, Hong Kong +0.55%, China -0.63% and ASX -0.08%.European mkts are all higher - breathing what feels like is a sigh of relief.....German factory orders the only notable report....and they weren't good....falling by 0.7% vs. the estimate of -0.5%....FTSE +0.48%, CAC 40 + -0.48%, DAX -0.06%, EUROSTOXX +0.38%, SPAIN +1.28% AND ITALY +0.64%.US futures are now UP 2 pts....as the clock ticks on the 8:30 bombshell......What will the gov't tell us today about Non Farm Payrolls and the jobs created? Will it 'blow the doors off the bus?' Expectations are for +200k jobs, but in reality – the range is +150/+220. Anything less than 150k will only add to the angst of a slowing economy – remember what Challenger Gray and Christmas told us yesterday morning…..We announced lay OFFS of 75k people last month – so an NFP that ‘blows the doors off the bus' would hardly be believable at all….

(but hey - has no one ever MASSAGED the numbers?)I can't wait.....but watch the action in the moments before the official release.....as it is entirely possible that someone has the edge...... After the bell last night we heard once again from KC Fed President Mester (Hawk)....but it appears that her comments are being discounted as the focus turns to Janet Yellen's - Humphrey Hawkins Testimony next week.Take good care.KpFollow Kenny Polcari on Twitter and Kenny Polcari.comKenny Polcari is Vice President and director of NYSE Floor Operations on behalf of O’Neil Securities, Inc., a sister company of Investor's Business Daily. Did department stores Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN) move their earnings out of the doldrums and back onto the growth track in the third quarter?Investors will learn the answer when the two top department stores kick off retail earnings season and report quarterly results this week. If analysts' expectations are on target, both companies will see their earnings decrease.So far, the signs aren't good, analysts say. The department store group saw their shares get hammered on Monday as several negative reports came out on the segment.Macy's shares tumbled after Citigroup lowered its price target on the retailer. Deutsche Bank also issued a negative report on Macy's and other mid-tier department store operators Kohl's (KSS) and Dillard's (DDS), noting they "may be about to limbo underneath what is already a very low bar as they report potentially very underwhelming Q3 results and Q4/holiday guidance."Macy's shares closed down 5.4% on the stock market today.JPMorgan also issued a negative report on several department stores on Monday noting Macy's, Dillard's, Kohl's and Nordstrom have "too much cold-weather inventory," among other things. Nordstrom shares closed down 4.7% on Monday.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Macy's to see earnings decline 13% from a year earlier to 53 cents a share when it reports third-quarter results on Wednesday before the opening bell. That comes on top of a 20% drop in the second quarter.They see a 1.6% decline in sales to $6.1 billion, following a 3% decrease in the second quarter, to mark the third straight quarter of year-over-year earnings declines.Macy's is generally regarded as a well-run chain, with a strong sales channels, but it has reported lower year-over-year revenue in five of the last seven quarters.The sales trend comes as spending has been shifting from traditional shopping-mall department stores and apparel chains toward experiences and non-tangible goods such as wireless services and entertainment, amid ever-growing competition from Amazon (AMZN) and other online players.Investor's Business Daily's department store industry group ranks retailers No. 192 out of 197 industry groups.Macy's has recently undertaken a number of initiatives to propel growth, including entering the lucrative off-price retail arena, where it would compete with operators such as TJX Cos. (TJX) and Ross Stores (ROST). In September, Macy's debuted its new off-price retail brand, Macy's Backstage, with three New York City metro area stores and three more set to open in 2015.Nordstrom is also generally regarded as a well-run chain with a strong omnichannel presence. The company has fared particularly well with its growing chain of Nordstrom Rack off-price stores.Nordstrom is expected to see earnings slip 0.7% vs. a year earlier to 72 cents a share when the high-end department store operator reports third-quarter results on Thursday after the close. That would follow a 2% decline in adjusted earnings in the second quarter and mark the fourth-straight quarterly drop in earnings.Analysts expect the upscale department store operator to see a 7.4% rise in revenue to $3.4 billion. That would follow a 9% gain in sales in the second quarter.On Oct. 1, Nordstrom announced that it closed the sale of its credit card portfolio to TD Bank USA for $2.2 billion. The agreement also makes TD Bank the exclusive U.S. issuer of Nordstrom-branded Visa and private-label consumer credit cards.In connection with the closing, Nordstrom's board authorized a special cash dividend and an additional $1 billion share repurchase program. The company said it would pay a special cash dividend of $4.85 a share on Oct. 27, to shareholders of record on Oct. 12.Follow Marilyn Much on Twitter @IBD_MMuch.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting 55 cents. Revenue edged up 1.3% to $4.12 billion, under views for $4.18 billion. Same-store sales were up 1.4%, but analysts polled by…

Initial jobless claims sank last week to a seven-year low of 297,000, the Labor Department said. Two regional manufacturing surveys also signaled strength in early May. But those…

Kohl's (KSS) shares plunged 19% Thursday after the department store chain cut full-year guidance and reported shaky sales in the fourth quarter.The company lowered its fiscal 2015 outlook to $3.40 to $3.45 in diluted per-share earnings. Excluding certain items, diluted EPS is expected to be $3.95 to $4, down from prior guidance for the low end of $4.40 to $4.60 a share, and below Wall Street forecasts for $4.30 a share."While we experienced our fifth consecutive quarter of positive comparable sales increases, sales were very volatile and less than planned in the fourth quarter," said Kohl's CEO Kevin Mansell in a statement. Holiday sales were strong, but those gains were offset by a "very slow start" to the quarter and a weaker-than-expected January on low demand for cold-weather gear.An unseasonably warm start to winter caused trouble for many other retailers, elevating inventory levels and prompting promotional activity.The company, which reports Q4 and full 2015 earnings Feb. 25, said Q4 same-store sales ticked up 0.4%, below Retail Metrics' forecast for 0.8% comp growth. Comps for all of fiscal 2015 grew 0.7%.Total Q4 sales rose 0.8%, it said. Full-year sales grew 1%.Shares of department store peer Macy's (M) closed down 2% in the stock market today. J.C. Penney (JCP) shares lost 4.8%.

The retail giant, which announced a 25% dividend hike, said business improved in April. Macy's earnings rose 9% from a year earlier to 60 cents a share, 1 cent above forecasts by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. That…

Investors will get an idea of how the harsh winter weather impacted consumer spending when Macy's (M) and several other retail giants report earnings this week.If followers are on target, top department-store operator Macy's saw a slowing of earnings growth from the past two quarters and a bit of an uptick in sales growth compared with the fourth quarter's gain. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Macy's to post a 7.3% increase in earnings from a year earlier to 59 cents a share when it reports first-quarter results before the open on Wednesday. That would be a slowdown from the double-digit gains it saw the prior two quarters. They see sales rising 1.3% to $6.47 billion, compared with a 2% decline in the fourth quarter.Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) will report earnings before the opening bell on Thursday. Analysts expect the world's largest retailer to see earnings rise 1% from a year earlier to $1.15 a share. That would be an improvement from the fourth quarter's 4% earnings decline.Analysts forecast that revenue will rise 2% to $116.249 billion. That would be the same growth that Wal-Mart saw in the prior three quarters.Thursday will be a busy one for major retailers. Value department stores Kohl's (KSS) and J.C. Penney (JCP), as well as upscale Nordstrom (JWN), all report earnings that day. Kohl's and Nordstrom are expected to report modest year-over-year EPS declines. JCPenney should post its ninth straight quarterly loss, with many more forecast going forward.Kohl's reports before Thursday's open, while Nordstrom and J.C. Penney release results after the market close.

Stocks were in the black in early afternoon trading Thursday after shaking off early losses from disappointing economic data and earnings reports.The Dow Jones industrial average led with a 0.4% gain, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq were up 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. Volume was mixed, tracking higher on the NYSE but lower on the Nasdaq. Winners outpaced losers by about a 2-1 margin on both major exchanges.The market stumbled early as weekly jobless claims came in higher than forecast, at 285,000 vs. 280,000, and December factory orders fell 2.9% in December, worse than views for a 2.8% dip. Crude oil prices were down 0.6% midday, while gold climbed more than 1%.Apparel makers, department stores and other retailers saw big declines in the stock market today. Ralph Lauren (RL) gapped down, tumbling 19% in massive volume to a five-year low after reporting fiscal Q3 profit that beat but sales that missed views. The premium lifestyle apparel maker also guided fiscal 2016 sales below expectations.Kohl's (KSS) also gapped down, sinking 18% to fall well below its 50-day moving average in active trade. Shares are 47% off their April high. The department store operator slashed its fiscal 2015 earnings outlook to $3.95-$4 a share ex items, down from the $4.40-$4.60 it projected earlier and below consensus estimates for $4.30. It reports quarterly and full-year results on Feb. 25.Steel, gold miners and transportation stocks scored big gains. Solar issues also advanced, with SolarEdge Technologies (SEDG) leading the charge on a 9% jump in robust trade. Late Wednesday, the Tesla Motors (TSLA) battery partner reported fiscal Q2 results that topped views and offered Q3 sales guidance well above forecasts. FBR on Thursday raised its SolarEdge price target to 38 from 36.On the IBD 50, Prestige Brands Holdings (PBH) soared 11% in fast turnover, recapturing its 200-day and 50-day lines. Shares are 8% off their peak. The maker of over-the-counter drugs and household cleaning products' fiscal Q3 results beat estimates on both the top and bottom lines.

Despite global economic and financial market headwinds, Friday's retail sales report signaled that the U.S. consumer can keep the world's largest economy growing. Retail sales rose 0.2% in January, the Commerce Department said, matching forecasts, as Amazon.com (AMZN) and other online retailers reported accelerating year-over-year growth. Even better, December sales were revised upward to a 0.2% gain compared with the previously reported…

The U.S. economy sputtered into the end of last year, but consumers were charging into the new year, with credit card debt rising at the fastest pace in more than seven years. Consumer credit outstanding, which includes all consumer borrowing outside of mortgages, rose by annualized $21.27 billion in December to $3.55 trillion, according to Federal Reserve data. Economists had expected…

Corporate America faces its first back-to-back earnings decline since the Great Recession, as a strong dollar weakens U.S. multinationals well beyond the oil patch. With 63% of S&P 500 companies reporting results as of Friday morning, Q4 earnings are on track to decline 4.1%, worse than the 3.7% retreat forecast at the beginning of the year, according to data compiled by Thomson Reuters.…
Gap Inc. (GPS) will let investors know how it fared during the cold winter weather blast that slammed many retailers when it reports first-quarter results on Thursday after the close.

The large apparel retailer may well show that it had some rough sledding based on its pre-announced first-quarter results on May 8. The company expects earnings per share to be in the range of 56 cents to 57 cents for the quarter ended May 3. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters forecast 57 cents a share. That would be a 20% decline from a year earlier and would follow a 7% drop in earnings in the prior quarter.
Gap said net sales increased 1% to $3.77 billion. Same-store sales slipped 1% from a year earlier.
Gap would be among a slew of retailers that saw a weak first quarter as the frosty winter weather sent shoppers into hibernation and dampened sales of spring merchandise.

But Gap saw business heat up in April, when it turned out strong same-store sales growth of 9% from a year earlier. That was well above forecasts for a 0.5% decline, according to Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics. The strong surge was buoyed by an 18% increase in same-store sales at its Old Navy chain.
The overall climate for the industry could be improving.
Warmer weather in April and a late Easter helped fuel holiday-related purchases and unleashed pent-up demand, driving strong same-store sales for monthly-reporting retailers, according to Perkins.

Among apparel retailers, Victoria's Secret parent L Brands (LB) saw an 8% rise in April same-store sales, topping views. Also posting April sales above forecasts was off-price retailer Stein Mart (SMRT), which rang up a strong 8.9% gain in April same-store sales.

Off-price retail operatorTJX Cos. (TJX) posted disappointing first-quarter results Tuesday. But CEO Carol Meyrowitz said: "While sales were not as strong as we would have liked, predominantly in our apparel business, I was very pleased that overall business trends improved as the quarter progressed."

She echoed the sentiments of other retailers that suggest a potential thaw in the retail climate. Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) and Kohl's (KSS) both said business improved as the first quarter progressed, after posting disappointing results last week.Gap Inc. In the fall of 1977, Jerome Chazen, a top executive at a new women's clothing firm called Liz Claiborne Inc., got a breathless call from a saleswoman in Dallas. Her department store had sold four skirts one Saturday afternoon, much more than usual. Chazen asked for more information about the buyers. The saleswoman said that a single shopper was responsible…
When it comes to the shoe business, Skechers USA seems bent on running a marathon.
Learning from the dramatic rise and fall of curved-bottom toning shoes a few years ago, the footwear firm won't rely on one hot product anymore to win the race.

Like a fashion maven who must have the newest styles, Skechers (SKX) is continuously changing and updating its footwear to keep up with fast-moving trends. Its closet is brimming with new styles, colors, materials and fits, covering everything from slip-ons and sneakers to high-performance running shoes.
"They have a very broad assortment of product that looks pretty good, but nothing controversial (like Shape-up toning shoes)," said analyst Sam Poser of Sterne Agee, meaning that as a compliment.
And the company is controlling inventory levels, he says. That way it won't be left with too much product to clear out at deep markdowns.
"When toning was popular they focused all their resources on toning and forgot about the rest of their business," said analyst Danielle McCoy of Brean Capital.
But over the past couple of years, she says, management has been updating and broadening assortments across all brand categories while also spreading awareness through multimedia marketing programs.
"They're focused on long-term sustainable profitability," McCoy said. "We started to see results of that over the last eight quarters."
From Toning To Rebounding
Following its swing from profit to a 2011 loss of 60 cents a share, Skechers got back on track in 2012. The company has been delivering a string of triple-digit year-over-year quarterly profit gains.

First-quarter earnings this year sprang to 61 cents a share from 13 cents a year earlier on a diluted basis, fueled by double-digit gains in the company's wholesale business and 5.6% same-store-sales growth at Skechers' stores.
Total revenue in the quarter grew 21% to $546.5 million. Both profit and revenue soundly beat analysts' consensus expectations.
Analysts anticipate revenue for the full year to increase 17% from last year to $2.16 billion. Earnings are seen rising 86% to $2.16 a share.
"We've seen strong results over the last year from redeveloped and innovative product and that is resonating with the consumer," said Jeff Van Sinderen, an analyst at B. Riley & Co.
Skechers does well with kids and adults, but has largely left the teen space to others, to avoid the fashion risks associated with notoriously fickle teen consumers, analysts say.

"Teens want the latest fashions and if you miss that next fashion trend you have to liquidate product," McCoy said. "Skechers is focused on the longer term, and that pretty much means casual men's and women's" and kids'.
McCoy noted in an early June report that retailers were increasing orders for the back-to-school season and that backlogs this year were up 30% over last year.

Manhattan Beach, Calif.-based Skechers sells at wholesale to department stores such as Macy's (M) and Kohl's (KSS), as well as specialty stores and footwear retailers such as Brown Shoe (BWS)'s Famous Footwear, DSW (DSW) and Shoe Carnival (SCVL). The company also sells to venues overseas.
Products are also sold at company-owned Skechers stores. There were 399 such outlets as of March 31, with 10 opening in Q1. Most are in the U.S. Fifty to 60 more stores are set to open by year-end.

Domestic and international wholesale sales account for 75% of revenue, with retail sales comprising most of the rest. E-commerce makes up just 1%. International growth is accelerating, especially in China, Hong Kong and Singapore, Christopher Svezia, an analyst at Susquehanna Financial Group, wrote in a research note.
"At 27% of sales, international could begin to catch U.S. wholesale within the next three years," he wrote.

In the first-quarter news release in late April, Skechers CEO Robert Greenberg said positive overall selling trends should continue through the second half of the year due to high demand for "key product initiatives" worldwide. (He and other executives were unavailable to comment ahead of the company's second-quarter earnings report.)
Comfort Is Key
The company has been rolling out new comfort footwear — such as "relaxed" fits and shoes cushioned with memory foam, which have spread from the active to casual collections.
It has also been featuring fresh colors. In the footwear industry, Svezia said in a phone interview, "comfort and color are performing very well. That bodes well for Skechers."
While "not a lot is going on in apparel," he says, accessories such as handbags and footwear have taken up the slack.

Skechers products are "aligning with what is essentially a very strong trend in active and athletic-derivative (footwear)," Van Sinderen added. "What are females wearing today? A lot of leggings, yoga pants. Skechers sits in the sweet spot of selling footwear that links up with active apparel."

McCoy notes that memory foam is a steppingstone to more advanced technologies planned for launches next spring. Those developments include a new GOmat insole that mixes memory foam with gel for cushion and "rebound support," the latter being important for running.
A new GOwalk women's line will also debut next spring, she says.

The GOwalk line is something of a sore point for Skechers, which in June filed a lawsuit against larger rival Adidas AG's Reebok International for selling footwear that it says infringes on its proprietary GOwalk product line.
A Run Against Nike
Performance shoes, whether for running, walking or gym workouts, are still a relatively small portion of Skechers' revenue. McCoy estimates the category accounts for about 15% of sales.
But the still-young business "has been doing amazingly well and continues to grow," she said. "It's a significant opportunity."

Marathon runner Meb Keflezighi, a 2004 Olympic silver medalist, won the 2014 Boston Marathon in Skechers' new GOmeb Speed 3 shoes. He's been on Skechers' celebrity endorsement team since 2011. It includes, among others, former quarterback Joe Montana and billionaire investor-entrepreneur Mark Cuban, who owns the Dallas Mavericks NBA basketball team and film-industry holdings.

The Skechers brand is gaining market share within the mid-tier channel "where newness was needed," Svezia wrote. "This has allowed the brand to attack the 'white space' below the Nike (NKE) and Adidas of the world and gain share."When it comes to the shoe business, Skechers USA seems bent on running a marathon.Learning from the dramatic rise and fall of curved-bottom toning shoes a few years ago, the footwear firm won't rely on one hot product anymore to win the race.Like a fashion maven who must have the newest styles, Skechers (SKX) is continuously changing and updating its footwear to keep up with fast-moving trends. Its closet is brimming with new styles, colors, materials and fits, covering everything from slip-ons and sneakers to high-performance running shoes."They have a very broad assortment of product that looks pretty good, but nothing controversial (like Shape-up toning shoes)," said analyst Sam Poser of Sterne Agee, meaning that as a compliment.And the company is controlling inventory levels, he says. That way it won't be left with too much product to clear out at deep markdowns."When toning was popular they focused all their resources on toning and forgot about the rest of their business," said analyst Danielle McCoy of Brean Capital.But over the past couple of years, she says, management has been updating and broadening assortments across all brand categories while also spreading awareness through multimedia marketing programs."They're focused on long-term sustainable profitability," McCoy said. The productivity of U.S. workers fell more than expected in the fourth quarter as hiring picked up even as the economy slowed. That negative combination for corporate profits contributed to a surge in layoffs in January, as retailers such as Wal-Mart (WMT) and Macy's (M)  joined  Halliburton (HAL), Schlumberger (SLB) and other oil companies announcing workforce restructurings, Challenger, Gray & Christmas reported.…

Stocks reversed out of early losses to narrow gains Thursday, heavily influenced by fluctuations in oil and other commodities. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 climbed 0.5% each. The Nasdaq was up 0.4%. Volume was mixed, up 30% on the NYSE but 1% lower on the Nasdaq, relative to action at the same time Thursday. A sliding dollar…
Stocks reversed higher at the closing bell Monday, ending a four-session skid despite another rout in China's stock market and a further drop in oil prices.

The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.3% and the S&P 500 edged up 0.1%, while the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%. Volume in the stock market today rose 10% on the Nasdaq and 6% on the NYSE compared with Friday, according to preliminary data.
Energy, mining and biotech stocks lagged, while department store, hospital and tobacco stocks led the upside.
Aluminum producer Alcoa (AA) rose after hours following its Q4 earnings report. The stock ended the regular session down nearly 1%, declining for the eighth straight session.

Macy's (M) led the S&P 500, rising 8% in strong volume after investment advisory firm Starboard Value reportedly said Monday it supports the department store's recent joint ventures for its mall-based and real estate properties. Other department store stocks also rallied, with Kohl's (KSS) rising 5% and Dillard's (DDS) 2%.

On a sour note, IBD 50 stock Celgene (CELG) dropped nearly 6% to its lowest level in over four months. The biotech offered 2016 guidance and named COO Mark Alles as its new CEO starting March 1. Current chief Bob Hugin will become executive chairman.
Companies due to report quarterly results Tuesday include CSX (CSX) and IHS (IHS).

Stocks fell into the red in early afternoon trading after initially shrugging off another rout in China's stock market. The Nasdaq shed 0.8%, the S&P 500 0.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.3%. Volume was mixed, tracking lower on the NYSE but higher on the Nasdaq. Losers topped winners by a 2-to-1 margin on the NYSE and nearly 3-to-2 on the Nasdaq.Energy, gold miners and biotechs lagged in the stock market today, while department store, hospital and tobacco stocks led the upside.Macy's (M) rose 4% in volume. The struggling stock is 48% off its 52-week high. Investment advisory firm Starboard Value on Monday said it supports the department store's recent joint ventures for its mall-based and real estate properties, reports said.Among other department store stocks, Kohl's (KSS) rallied 6% and Dillard's (DDS) 2%.Cruise ship operators also sailed ahead. Carnival (CCL) jumped 5% in heavy volume after finding support at its 50-day moving average. It's now back near a 54.69 buy point initially cleared Dec. 29. Analysts expect earnings to grow 24% in fiscal 2016 and 16% in 2017.Rival cruise line Royal Caribbean Cruises (RCL) lifted 3% in fast trade, on track to snap a six-session decline. The stock is still below its 50-day line and has slipped back into a flat base.The biggest loser on the IBD 50 was Celgene (CELG), which sank 6% to its lowest level in over four months. The stock has been consolidating since July, though it's now slumped to 10% below its 50-day line. The biotech offered 2016 guidance and named COO Mark Alles as its new CEO starting March 1. Current chief Bob Hugin will become executive chairman.The top IBD 50 gainer was aerospace gear maker TransDigm (TDG), up 3% to retake its 50-day and 200-day lines. Shares are working on a flat base with a potential buy point at 238.61.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter @IBD_NGondo and on Facebook.

Special Report: CES 2016 Tech Show NewsLAS VEGAS — As Fitbit ([STOCK[FIT]]) stock fell hard for a third straight day, the company's chief executive remained upbeat that the maker of wearable fitness devices is on the right track.In an interview with IBD on Thursday, Fitbit co-founder and CEO James Park defended the company's "smart fitness watch," the Fitbit Blaze, announced Tuesday at the CES trade show. Some analysts speculated that the device could fare poorly against the full-featured Apple ([STOCK[AAPL]]) Watch smartwatch."There's clearly a disconnect between investors and what our customers and retail partners are excited about," Park said. "We've had a lot of great meetings at CES with Wal-Mart ([STOCK[WMT]]), Target ([STOCK[TGT]]), Kohl's ([STOCK[KSS]]), etc. They expect Blaze to do really well. And the feedback we're getting from customers (is positive)."The Fitbit Blaze fills a gap in the company's product lineup, he said. It's targeted at fitness enthusiasts who want a device with a bigger screen that has more general-purpose capabilities.For Fitbit, the device will provide a higher average selling price and offers high-margin accessories.Fitbit Blaze will cost $199 when it goes on sales in March. That's a "sweet spot" for consumers, Park said. By comparison, the entry-level Apple Watch costs $349.People like to speculate about how competitive Fitbit is with Apple, but Park says that's not his concern."Ultimately we are focused on our customers," Park said. "General-purpose smartwatches really haven't taken off. There's confusion about what they're good for. Consumers are confused by the shear amount of stuff that these devices can do."So, look, our focus is: Fitness first. Our mission is around digital health, having devices and services that address people's lifestyle health goals, and in the future, hopefully more chronic conditions."Meanwhile, new competitors in the fitness tracker space emerged at CES including Under Armour ([STOCK[UA]]), Fossil ([STOCK[FOSL]]) and New Balance.Fitbit has successfully fended off such rivals as Nike ([STOCK[NKE]]) and Philips, Park said. It will continue to focus on its competitive advantages of its large user base and community features.Park says it's still early days for market penetration of wearable fitness devices.Fitbit also is facing a consumer class-action lawsuit about the accuracy of the heart-rate monitors on its fitness bands. Park said the lawsuit is without merit."Consumers are really happy with the device," Park said. "All you have to do is go to Amazon ([STOCK[AMZN]]) and see the reviews for Charge HR. Regardless of what the litigation says from the plaintiffs' attorneys, you have to look at the true consumer sentiment and I think people are pretty satisfied."Fitbit stock fell 6.1% to 21.50 on the stock market today, hitting a record low for a third straight day. Fitbit stock fell 18.4% on Tuesday and 5.8% on Wednesday, as the stock market overall corrected. On Thursday, Fitbit came close to hitting its IPO price of 20 from last June, but it closed its first day of trading near 30.
